As such, traits to which you give a magical origin can't be dispelled with {@spell Dispel Magic|XPHB} and similar effects, and are unaffected by magical dead zones or wild magic zones, the {@spell Antimagic Field|XPHB} spell, and so on.

entries.name: Trait List
entries: Heritage traits are grouped into three categories: Combat, Exploration, and Roleplaying. Traits of each group are listed below in alphabetical order, along with the name of the improved version of the trait if it is taken more than once. This list includes the traditional traits identified for each of the heritages described in the previous section.

items: {@optfeature Light Armor Training|GrimHollowPG24} → Light Armor Expertise
{@optfeature Medium Armor Training|GrimHollowPG24} → Heavy Armor Training
{@optfeature Touch of Life|GrimHollowPG24} → Strength of Life
{@optfeature Inured to the Elements|GrimHollowPG24} → Immune to the Elements
{@optfeature Shroud of the Wild|GrimHollowPG24} → Faultless Shroud
{@optfeature Connection to Nature|GrimHollowPG24} → Bond with Nature
{@optfeature Gifted Performer|GrimHollowPG24} → A Sight to Behold
{@optfeature Moved by Faith|GrimHollowPG24} → Force of Faith

entries.name: Trait Descriptions
entries: The following traits define your character, establishing who they were at birth and who they've become since then. Though your character's capabilities are largely defined by your choice of class, these traits provide the tools to tailor your character's other physical, mental, and magical potential.
{@homebrew Please refer to section above for descriptions.|Trait Descriptions section}

data.name: Chapter 2: Classes & Subclasses
entries: Adventurers specialize in their abilities and outlooks based on the culture in which they train and advance. Characters in the world of Etharis are influenced by dark and sometimes malevolent powers, delving into areas others might avoid.

The new class, the Monster Hunter and its subclasses, as well as the other subclasses here, reflect back onto the heroes and the world in which they live and fight. Some absorb into themselves the dangerous but powerful forces they fight. What that acceptance of terrible power means on the psyches of the adventurers can be varied; however, one cannot deny that delving into the darkness to find strength often comes at a steep and sometimes fatal cost.

As you play with these new player options, reflect on how the common folk that the characters interact with accept and react to them. Are these powers visible to bystanders when they are used? If so, do they mimic or even exemplify the types of powers used by the monsters that the commoners fear?

The new class and subclasses offer play that reflects not just the story of dark fantasy that is presented by Grim Hollow, but also an attention to detail and tactics that are promoted in a dark fantasy game. Monster Hunters specialize in hunting particular types of monsters. That means that the stories, plots, and tactics the characters use should reflect that. It matters when the characters are fighting Beasts as opposed to Monstrosities. This level of granularity is embraced rather than glossed over in the best dark fantasy games and stories. Lean into those stories—and that game play—to get the most out of the rules presented here.

entries.name: Class & Subclass Overview
entries: This chapter provides a wealth of character class options to explore in your Grim Hollow campaigns. You'll find the new Monster Hunter class along with four subclasses for your character to specialize in. Additionally, each of the standard Fifth Edition character classes is expanded with three Grim Hollow-themed subclasses, helping you explore the innumerable dark stories of Etharis.

entries: Harness your primal power to tear through your enemies. Follow the Path of the ...

items: {@b {@i Primal Spirit}} to summon a spectral ally.
{@b {@i Wrathful Dead}} to channel the restless dead.

entries: Use your performing skills to harness magic and inspire your allies. Join the College of ...

items: {@b {@i Adventurers}} to use all the knowledge of adventuring.
{@b {@i Fools}} to kill foes with laughter.
{@b {@i Requiems}} to sing praises of the dead.

entries: Shape the lingering divine powers of Etharis to manifest its power. Then tap into the ...

items: {@b {@i Eldritch Domain}} to wield god-killing power.
{@b {@i Inquisition Domain}} to cleanse the heretics.
{@b {@i Purification Domain}} to purge sickness via suffering.

entries.name: Druid

{@b {@i Mutation}} to tap the power of change.

{@b {@i Living Crucible}} to enhance fighting through alchemy.
{@b {@i Nightwatcher}} to take back the night.

entries: Train yourself, body and spirit, in the mechanics of martial arts. Hone your skills as a Warrior of ...

items: {@b {@i Leaden Crown}} to fight against the tyranny of power.
{@b {@i Pride}} to make the best version of yourself.
{@b {@i Regret}} to atone for past mistakes.

{@b {@i Devourer Guild}} to consume monsters to gain power.
{@b {@i Occultist Guild}} to fight magic with magic.
{@b {@i Trapper Guild}} to employ traps to defeat monsters.

entries.name: Paladin
entries: Devote yourself to a cause greater than yourself. Take a binding pledge to the Oath of ...

{@b {@i Slaughter}} to revel in unbridled violence.

entries.name: Monster Hunter Guilds
entries: A Monster Hunter subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Monster Hunter levels, as specified in the subclass. This section presents the Carver Guild, Devourer Guild, Occultist Guild, and Trapper Guild subclasses.

Hunting guilds are groups of Monster Hunters who use the same teachings and techniques. Some guilds are formally organised like a mercenary company, while others are more loosely organized but have inherited similar knowledge.

entries.name: Barbarian Subclasses
entries: Mindless rage is an enticing offering provided by some of the darker forces of Etharis. Some barbarians embrace this, while others reject it, seeking aid from the spirits of nature or from deep within their own minds.

images.title: {@subclass Primal Spirit|Barbarian|XPHB|GrimHollowPG24|Path of the Primal Spirit}
{@subclass Wrathful Dead|Barbarian|XPHB|GrimHollowPG24|Path of the Wrathful Dead}

entries.name: Bard Subclasses
entries: Etharis is a realm rife with fear and danger, and the brave folk who face that darkness every day. Bards of the realm channel that bravery, either to bring hope to those on the brink of hopelessness, or to turn that darkness back onto their foes, dancing on the thin line between comedy and tragedy.

entries.name: Cleric Subclasses
entries: In a world bereft of gods, clerics have to find strength wherever it presents itself. Some turn to even higher and more esoteric powers, while others focus on more worldly matters like driving out heretic mages and purging the unclean.

entries.name: Druid Subclasses
entries: The druids of Etharis are as violent and unforgiving as the realms and nature themselves. They are the twisted and disfigured monsters that chase trespassers from the woods, the stern wardens of death and entropy, or the haggard wretches offering living sacrifices under a crimson sky.

entries.name: Fighter Subclasses
entries: Fighters in Etharis embody the staunch defiance of mortals. They range from seasoned warriors who have trained for years to be a shield against the dark, to commonfolk that have become competent combatants out of necessity. Among them there are even some who have turned to magic and experimental alchemy for the slightest edge in battling the constant danger that defines life in Etharis.

entries.name: Monk Subclasses
entries: Monks in Etharis are varied and unique. Some seek discipline to atone for past sins or to root out corruption, while others embrace a less selfless path, displaying awe-inspiring feats of martial prowess for their own gain.

images.title: {@subclass Leaden Crown|Monk|XPHB|GrimHollowPG24|Warrior of the Leaden Crown}

entries.name: Paladin Subclasses
entries: Most paladins in Etharis are beholden to an ideal rather than any higher power. Whether that is to spread disease and ruin, to root out and destroy heretics, or to kill for the simple love of bloodshed, these are warriors who fight mercilessly for their chosen cause.

entries.name: Ranger Subclasses
entries: Rangers in Etharis are skilled and knowledgeable warriors. Ranging from master assassins and poison experts to stalwart guardians of the natural world and commanders of vast armies of rodents and vermin, in many parts of the realm they are the last line of defense for the fading natural world.

entries.name: Rogue Subclasses
entries: From gunslinging highway bandits to skulking blood mages and walking jinxes capable of stealing luck itself, rogues in Etharis use cunning and deception to survive, and when that doesn't work, a well-placed blade typically does the trick.

entries.name: Sorcerer Subclasses
entries: With so many otherworldly forces at play, there is no shortage of folks whose very beings have been infused with magic. Sorcerers in Etharis range from raving scholars plagued with visions of the end of days, to spirit-callers and those suffering curses for the sins of their ancestors.

entries.name: Warlock Subclasses
entries: Whether the servant of scheming hags, ancient and powerful vampires, or unmentionable horrors from beyond the cosmos, warlocks in Etharis often find themselves pawns in the twisted machinations of some greater esoteric being. Whether they are content to play along or have plans of their own that take precedence is entirely up to their wishes and whim, the nature of their pacts, and their willingness to oppose such powerful beings.

entries.name: Wizard Subclasses
entries: With the use of arcane magic becoming a taboo punishable by slow and painful death in certain parts of Etharis, Wizards have broadened the scope of their clandestine practices. Some have turned to unraveling the secrets of divinity, while others turned to more worldly magic, combining science and alchemy with the arcane to inflict and cure disease. Others have delved into even darker pursuits, becoming masters of blood magic.

data.name: Chapter 3: Backgrounds
entries: Character backgrounds in a Grim Hollow campaign represent far more than just your occupation or situation before becoming an adventurer. They often represent a transformative or life-changing experience that led you to become the person you are. This does involve training, of course. But it can be so much more.

The different national situations and perspectives in Etharis means that you are no mere sage—a sage from {@book Valika|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Valikan Clans} is very much different than a sage from {@book Liesech|GrimHollowPG24|8|The City of Liesech}. An acolyte training in the sun-starved chapels of {@book Ostoya|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Ostoyan Empire} should look at the world much differently than the strictly regimented abbeys of {@book Castinella|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Castinellan Provinces}.

As you select from the character backgrounds presented in this chapter, ask yourself what about your character's experiences up to this point shaped their personality and drove their decisions. What made you want or need to leave the safety of the cathedral or college to pursue the dangers of the adventuring life? Was the choice yours alone, or did circumstances intervene to force you out into the wilds of Etharis?

entries.name: The Role of Backgrounds
entries: Character backgrounds are meant to be both storytelling tools as well as game-mechanical devices for delivering ability score increases, feats, proficiencies, and equipment. As you create your character, keep both of those aspects in mind. If there is some game element of a character background that doesn't meet the vision you have for your character, or if some game element of a character background is already provided by another aspect of your character, such as heritage or class, work with your GM to find a suitable replacement that is of similar power but better defines who your character is.
Backgrounds and Ability Scores

The base 5e 2024 rules indicate that some of your ability score increases come from your character background, and suggested abilities used for increases are listed within each background. As pointed out in {@book Chapter 1: Heritages and Traits|GrimHollowPG24|2}, we suggest that you do not limit which abilities can be increased based on character background. Regardless, if your campaign does limit abilities that can be increased based on backgrounds, we provide suggestions as per the base 5e 2024 rules.

entries.name: Grim Hollow Backgrounds
entries: The following character backgrounds should be used alongside those provided from other suitable sources when creating your Grim Hollow character. While the name of the background might be generic, you can change it to be more suitable for the character's backstory and role. For example, a Physician could be reflavored as a Clan Healer in {@book Valika|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Valikan Clans}, an Embalmer in {@book Liesech|GrimHollowPG24|8|The City of Liesech}, or a Corpse Collector in {@book Bürach|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Bürach Empire}.

data.name: Chapter 4: Character Feats
entries: From the immeasurably talented swordsmen of the Castinellan Blade Artisans to the ferocious Valikan Berserkers, Etharis is home to many individuals of deadly expertise. Feats are a great way to represent a character's honed skills or natural talent in a specific discipline.

As with the 2024 5e rules, characters gain Origin feats when they select backgrounds. General feats can be taken when a class feature or other rule allows a feat. Fighting Style feats add martial might to characters. And Epic Boons represent powerful achievements for characters in Etharis.
The following feats are divided by feat types: Origins, General, Fighting Style, and Epic Boon. Any prerequisites for the feat must be met before it can be selected.

entries.name: Origin Feats
entries: The following Origins feats are connected to the Grim Hollow backgrounds detailed in {@book chapter 3|GrimHollowPG24|4}.
I didn't think anyone would eat my cooking until I met Allegria. It was love at first taste.

entries.name: General Feats
entries: These feats are in the General category.

entries.name: Fighting Style Feats
entries: The following feats are in the Fighting Style category.

entries.name: Epic Boon Feats
entries: The following feats are in the Epic Boon category.

data.name: Chapter 5: Advanced Weapons & Equipment
entries: Over many centuries, the people of Etharis have created and perfected specialized equipment and weaponry to combat and destroy the nightmarish monsters of the world—and each other. Whether these objects take the form of alchemical ammunition, resilient armor, or devious weapons, most serve to either protect or destroy.

Warriors of all stripes have also developed sophisticated techniques, turning weapons of straightforward but precise design more deadly. Advanced equipment comprises both practices, from new weapons to novel ways of using familiar ones. To function as it should, each piece of Advanced equipment must be made with exactness, and each one is a masterpiece of the craft required to produce it. Hence, each piece of Advanced equipment has a high price. The {@book Advanced Weapon|GrimHollowPG24|6|Transformation Progression} table and {@book Advanced Equipment|GrimHollowPG24|6|Equipment} tables summarize these objects and their unique uses. Descriptions of these pieces of equipment include more details.

entries.name: Advanced Weapon Training
entries: Mastery of Advanced weapons requires military training and skill. To use any of the special properties or the Weapon Mastery properties of an Advanced weapon, you must take the {@feat Advanced Weapon Proficiency|GrimHollowPG24} feat.

entries.name: Advanced Weapon Properties
entries: The following properties are new or altered for Advanced weapons. Wielders of Advanced weapons have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls with these weapons unless they are proficient with the weapon.

entries.name: Armor-Piercing
entries: An Armor-Piercing weapon is a Melee weapon designed to punch through armor or thick hide. When you make an attack roll using an Armor-Piercing weapon, you gain a +1 bonus to the attack roll if your target is wearing armor or has an Armor Class of 18 or higher.

entries.name: Blackpowder
entries: Blackpowder weapons fire projectiles with ear-splitting noise, shredding armor with deadly force. When fired, Blackpowder weapons emit a deafening crack audible 300 feet away. A Blackpowder weapon exposed to heavy rain, submerged, or similarly drenched in water, can't fire until dried for 1 hour. These weapons use paper cartridge bullets as ammunition.

entries.name: Cumbersome
entries: Cumbersome weapons are difficult to wield but are effective ranged tools for those strong enough to wield them. When making an attack with a Cumbersome weapon, you must use your Strength modifier for the attack and damage rolls.

entries.name: Damage
entries: A Damage property weapon can deal different types of damage. When you hit with an attack from this weapon, choose one of the damage types allowed.

entries.name: Double
entries: A Double weapon functions as two {@itemProperty L|XPHB|Light} weapons, one in each hand, for the purposes of two-weapon fighting. If a Double weapon has the {@itemProperty R|XPHB|Reach} property, you can use only one of these properties per turn.

entries.name: Hafted
entries: A Hafted weapon's haft can function well as an off-hand attack. After you use the Attack action to attack with a Hafted weapon, you can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to make a melee attack with the haft. The haft deals {@damage 1d6} Bludgeoning damage, and you add your ability modifier to damage.

entries.name: Magazine
entries: A weapon with the Magazine property also has a number and an ammunition type. The weapon holds that amount and type of ammunition, which you can expend before needing to reload the weapon. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you may remove a {@item Magazine|GrimHollowPG24} and then reload it with a new {@item Magazine|GrimHollowPG24}. A Magazine weapon comes with two empty magazines included in the weapon's cost and weight. An additional empty magazine for a Magazine weapon costs 25 GP. {@itemProperty LD|XPHB|Loading} an empty Magazine with ammunition takes 1 minute.

entries.name: Momentum
entries: Momentum weapons allow you to deliver devastating attacks as part of rapid movement. When you hit with a Momentum weapon after you moved 20 feet or more in a straight line during the same turn, upgrade the damage dice to the weapon's Momentum Dice value.

entries.name: Repeater
entries: Repeater weapons can fire ammo in quick succession, using multiple barrels or quick-reloading mechanisms. When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action with a Repeater weapon, you can shoot multiple times if you have features that let you attack more than once as part of that action, such as Extra Attack. After taking the Attack action you can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to attack once with the same weapon. You don't add your ability modifier to the Bonus Action's attack, unless that modifier is negative.

entries.name: New Weapon Mastery Properties
entries: The following are new Mastery Properties usable by characters who have a feature, such as Weapon Mastery, that unlocks the property for the character. Characters must also be proficient with Advanced weapons to use any Mastery Properties of an Advanced weapon.

entries.name: Brutal
entries: A Brutal weapon is designed for maximum damage. Brutal weapons score Critical Hits on a natural roll of 19 or 20. If your Critical Range is already increased, instead increase it by 1 point (such as from 19-20 to 18-20). When you score a Critical Hit with a Brutal weapon against a creature, the weapon deals one additional die of damage.

entries.name: Defending
entries: A Defending weapon is either made for parrying, has advanced techniques for use in parrying, or both. When wielding a Defending weapon, you may use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} when you are hit by a melee attack roll. Roll {@dice 1d4} and add the result to your AC against the triggering attack.

entries.name: Disarming
entries: A Disarming weapon can catch a foe's weapon, allowing you to remove it from their grasp. When you take the Attack action on your turn and hit with a Disarming weapon, you can use your {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} later on the same turn to disarm the target. Both you and the attacker must make opposed attack rolls, ignoring any sources of {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} and {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}. If your result is higher and the weapon is something the target can drop, the weapon falls from the target's grasp, landing in its space.

If your winning result on the opposed attack roll was a Critical Hit, you can choose for the weapon either to land in a space of your choice up to 15 feet from the target, or to land in your hand if you have a free hand.

entries.name: Entangling
entries: When you take the Attack action on your turn and hit with an Entangling weapon, you can use a Bonus Action later on the same turn to entangle the target. The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw ({@dc 10} plus your Proficiency Bonus) or have the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition until it escapes or until you release the weapon. The target succeeds automatically if it is Huge or larger.

To escape, the target must use an action to make a Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) check against the same DC. On a success, the target no longer has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition. While a creature is Grappled by this weapon, you can't use it to attack a different creature.

entries.name: Returning
entries: A Returning weapon allows you to hurl the weapon in such a way that it returns to you. When you make a ranged attack with a Returning weapon, the weapon returns to you immediately after hitting or missing the target. You can catch the weapon if you have a hand free to do so.

entries.name: Scatter
entries: Scatter weapons can devastate multiple enemies at once. When you take the Attack action and hit a creature with a Scatter weapon, measure the weapon's scatter range from the target's space (or one square the creature occupies if it is Large or larger). Creatures other than the original target that fall within the weapon's scatter range take damage equal to your 1 + your Dexterity modifier (minimum 2). This damage is of the same type you dealt to the original target.

entries.name: Set
entries: Weapons with the Set property allow you to prepare for an oncoming attack. If a target enters your reach while you wield a weapon with this property, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to make a melee attack with the weapon against that target.

entries.name: Strong-Draw
entries: A weapon with the Strong-Draw quality requires great strength to use. You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls with a Strong-Draw weapon unless your Strength is 13 or higher. You add both your Strength and Dexterity modifiers to damage with a Strong-Draw weapon.

entries.name: Swift
entries: Swift weapons help you recover quickly from missed attacks. When you miss with a Swift weapon, you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on the first attack roll you make with the weapon against the same target before the end of your next turn. If that attack hits, it also deals an extra {@dice 1d4} damage of the weapon's normal damage type.

entries.name: Advanced Weapon Training: Ammunition
entries: Just as industrious crafters and disciplined masters have created advanced weapons and techniques, so too have they created ammunition to deal specialized damage. To utilize {@book Advanced Ammunition|GrimHollowPG24|6|Ammunition}, you must have proficiency with the weapon that uses the ammo, and you must be level 3 or higher.

entries.name: Damage Types
entries: Advanced Ammunition named after a damage type deals that damage type. Arrows and bolts can have wide heads that deal Slashing damage or blunt tips that deal Bludgeoning damage. A sling bullet can have facets that deal Piercing damage. All such ammo is heavier than normal; the weapon's maximum range while using it is halved.

entries.name: Ranging
entries: Advanced Ammunition that has the Ranging property is lighter and better made than common counterparts. When you fire Ranging ammo, you can increase your weapon's normal range by 50 percent.

entries.name: Whistling
entries: Ammunition with the Whistling property creates a high-pitched sound after firing. This sound is audible out to 300 feet from the ammo as it flies. Whistling ammo isn't heavier, but it catches the air with intricate baffles to create its sound, so its maximum range is half normal. Whistling ammo deals Bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Alchemical Ammunition
entries: Alchemical Ammunition carries an alchemical payload. Rather than hurling a vial, you fire Alchemical Ammunition from a Ranged weapon, using your normal attack bonus with that weapon.
Alchemical Ammunition is heavier than normal; the weapon's normal and long ranges are halved. The Alchemical Ammunition is destroyed once used, whether the attack hits or misses.

{@item Acid|XPHB}, {@item Alchemist's Fire|XPHB}, and {@item Holy Water|XPHB}. When one of these pieces of Alchemical Ammunition hits, it deals the ammunition's normal damage, then applies the effect of the listed item to the target. No saving throw is allowed against this effect.

{@item War Oil|GrimHollowPG24}. A target hit by a piece of Alchemical Ammunition packed with War Oil takes damage as normal for the ammunition, then becomes coated in War Oil for up to 1 minute. Alternatively, you can target a point, such as the ground or a wall, and on an attack roll against AC 10, cause the War Oil to spill out of the ammunition, creating a circular patch of the viscous substance with a 10-foot radius.

War Oil is slick and highly flammable. An area coated in War Oil counts as {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}, and a creature that starting its turn in a coated area or enters the coated area for the first time on a turn must succeed a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw or gain the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition and have its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} reduced to 0 until the end of its turn.

Additionally, if a creature or area coated with War Oil is exposed to an open flame or some other source of Fire damage, the oil ignites. The ignited oil burns for two rounds, dealing {@damage 2d4} Fire damage to any creature or object who comes in contact with it, and an additional {@damage 2d4} Fire damage to any creature that ends its turn while in contact with it. An ignited creature can douse the flames by using an action.
After burning for two rounds, being doused, or remaining unlit for 1 minute, War Oil dries up and ceases to be slippery or flammable.

entries.name: Specialized Ammunition Properties
entries: The following Advanced Ammunition properties impart more effectiveness to ammunition. Each piece of specialized ammunition can have only one of these properties. Because of the crafting skills required to make this ammunition, it is much more expensive.

entries.name: Armor-Piercing
entries: This ammunition works like an Armor-Piercing Melee weapon, but you fire the ammunition as a projectile from a Ranged weapon.

entries.name: Blessed
entries: When you hit with Blessed ammunition, the weapon's damage type becomes Radiant. Also, if the target is Fiend, Fey, or Undead, that creature's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is reduced by 10 feet until the end of its next turn, and the creature can't take {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions} until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Brutal
entries: Designed to open wide wounds, such as with a broad-bladed arrowhead, Brutal ammunition works like a Brutal Melee weapon.

entries.name: Desecrated
entries: When you hit with Desecrated ammunition, the weapon's damage type becomes Necrotic. Also, if the target is Celestial, Humanoid, or Plant, that creature's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is reduced by 10 feet until the end of its next turn, and the creature can't take Reactions until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Incendiary
entries: When you hit with Incendiary ammunition, the target takes an additional {@damage 1d4} Fire damage.

entries.name: Advanced Equipment
entries: The brilliant engineers and crafters who designed and built Etharis's highly advanced weapons and ammunition did not stop there. Other inventions of war—and of peace—became invaluable to the soldiers, guards, and adventurers of Etharis.

Some pieces of Advanced equipment, such as the corrupting {@item Shadowsteel Focus|GrimHollowPG24}, need special training to fully employ. Other items, like the Retractable Shield, are usable by anyone proficient with shields. And many other pieces of equipment are usable by anyone—though few would be able to afford and maintain these mechanical, alchemical, or even magical marvels.

As they are expensive and difficult to make, access to Advanced equipment is limited—maybe even as limited as some magic items. The largest cities, or locations housing master crafters, may only have a few items of Advanced equipment.
The following items are considered Advanced equipment.

entries.caption: Equipment
footnotes: *As per normal equipment of its type

entries.caption: Advanced Melee Weapons
footnotes: *Denotes an Advanced Weapon Property that can only be used by characters proficient with the weapon.

entries.caption: Advanced Ranged Weapons
rows: {@itemProperty AF|XDMG|Ammunition} (Range 20/80; Paper Cartridge Bullet), Blackpowder, {@itemProperty L|XPHB|Light}, {@itemProperty LD|XPHB|Loading}
{@itemProperty AF|XDMG|Ammunition} (Range 80/300; Paper Cartridge Bullet), Blackpowder, {@itemProperty LD|XPHB|Loading}, {@itemProperty 2H|XPHB|Two-Handed}
{@itemProperty AF|XDMG|Ammunition} (Range 30/90; Paper Cartridge Bullet), Blackpowder, Cumbersome, {@itemProperty LD|XPHB|Loading}, {@itemProperty 2H|XPHB|Two-Handed}
{@itemProperty AF|XDMG|Ammunition} (Range 15/60; Paper Cartridge Bullet), Blackpowder, {@itemProperty LD|XPHB|Loading}
{@itemProperty AF|XDMG|Ammunition} (Range 15; Bellows Cannister), Cumbersome, {@itemProperty LD|XPHB|Loading}, Magazine (20), {@itemProperty 2H|XPHB|Two-Handed}
{@itemProperty AF|XDMG|Ammunition} (Range 30/120; Blowgun Needle), {@itemProperty L|XPHB|Light}, Magazine (6), Repeater*
footnotes: *Denotes an Advanced Weapon Property that can only be used by characters proficient with the weapon.

data.name: Chapter 6: Transformations

entries.name: Part 2: Magic & Mutation
entries: Magic is a force that allows individuals and creatures to break the laws of nature. It can render the impossible mundane—or elevate the mundane into the spectacular. With the slightest twitch of the hand and the speaking of a simple word or phrase, the world can change in dramatic and amazing ways. At least, that's what the wielders of magic on Etharis want the common folk to believe.

The reality of magic on Etharis is much darker, more dangerous, and often terrifying. Nature is cruel and strange enough—magic only intensifies the terrible power that roils under the placid façade of the natural world.

Magic manifests itself most visibly in two areas in the world of Grim Hollow: {@book Transformations|GrimHollowPG24|8} and {@book spells|GrimHollowPG24|9}. Each of these magical elements is a manifestation of the temptation that leads people to seek to change themselves and the world around them through a dangerous and unpredictable force.

Spells are the more manageable—and typically less powerful—manifestations of the magic of Etharis. The force, when tamed into the form of a spell, allows for effects that are limited in scope. Curses are less predictable and more gruesome spells that, when they reach their full effects, are likely to destroy their targets. They may also take a toll on their casters.

Transformations are emblematic of the unpredictable and uncontrollable manifestation of magic. Transformations originate when a curse inherent in a creature passes on to another creature, or when a person opens themselves up to a more volatile form of magic that changes them at their very core.

The mutative aspects of a Transformation often affect the mind as much as they affect the body, leaving the creatures undergoing the Transformation both enhanced and hindered by the magic. And, like all magic in Etharis, corruption lies at the very heart of Transformation's mutation.

Etharis teems with monsters of countless varieties. Some are born monstrous; others are shaped into creatures of malice and cruelty. Others still became monsters through accidents or by choice. They became transformed.

What these transformed folks do with their newfound abilities—and how they deal with the monstrous urges that come with those abilities—might be the only delineation between whether they are seen as heroes or monsters.

entries.name: Why Transformations?
entries: The following rules provide players and GMs with the tools to see their characters slowly become grim monsters. From dread-inducing werewolves to all-powerful liches, and bloodthirsty vampires to plane-touched seraphs, the following Transformations are available to characters.

The stories that permeate fantasy—and especially those stories of dark fantasy, horror, and the gothic—tend to come tinged with themes of transformation. Tales of innocent victims turning into the same monsters that attack them in the dark forest are as old as time itself. Magic wielders dabbling in forbidden arcana, paying with their very souls for the hubris, permeate most cultures.

Making character Transformations—whether forced onto a creature or self-inflicted—viable within an RPG is a challenge. Sometimes the tropes are worked into a class itself, as we see with the blood-tainted Sorcerer or the pact-making Warlock.

These classes, however, often focus on only the positives. They show what these people have gained from their actions or backgrounds, but rarely do they capture the struggles that come with getting bitten by a lycanthrope, turned into a creature of the night by a vampire, or cursed with ghoul-hood by using the dangerous shadowsteel.

entries.name: Transformation Buy-In
entries: Transformations can add a layer of storytelling and tension to a campaign. The suspense of slowly turning into a monster is wonderful grist for the roleplaying mill, and being able to do things that a normal character cannot is fun!

But there are risks as well. The power that comes with a Transformation, as well as the drawbacks they represent, can give transformed characters a perceived (or real) advantage over other characters. Likewise, a drawback can be the end of a character, or the entire party, at the most inopportune time.

In addition to the issues of power, the roleplaying and narrative consequences of transformed characters can be far reaching and devastating. A character whose Transformation causes obvious supernaturally infused physical change is unlikely to escape the notice of a villager. Roleplaying those reactions every time can bog down a campaign; to ignore those reactions can make the point of the Transformation moot.

Before using Transformations in your campaign, discuss these issues so they do not harm the enjoyment of all the players and GM. While Transformations offer compelling narrative and mechanical opportunities, at no point do they provide an acceptable excuse to hurt the enjoyment of other players at the table.

entries.name: Beginning a Transformation
entries: Individuals rarely choose to change into monstrous beings. Most often, they have an affliction forced upon them. Foul curses, horrific experiments, and the diabolical machinations of fiends, vampires, and other dark agents are all examples of how a character might begin a Transformation.

There are times, however, when a character may wish to begin a Transformation of their own volition. Perhaps they have succumbed to the lure of power, or they see it as the only way to achieve a greater goal. Regardless, the first step in any Transformation should involve a discussion between the player, the GM, and the rest of the players involved in the campaign. Intentions should be clearly stated, as campaigns with a lighter tone or strict moral boundaries may not suit certain Transformations.

The next step in a Transformation is to ensure you meet the Transformation's prerequisites. These requirements, either narrative or game-mechanical, must be met for a character to start a Transformation. It is strongly recommended that these narrative prerequisites be attained through gameplay rather than through a backstory or other "offscreen" actions. However, a discussion for alternative avenues of meeting prerequisites can certainly take place.
Each of the Transformations that follows contains a section specifically focused on how a character might gain that Transformation, as well as how the first stages of the Transformation begin.
We told her we'd support her to become whatever she wanted.

entries.name: Transformation Stages
entries: Each Transformation has four stages. Characters reach a new stage of a Transformation when a certain milestone or trigger occurs. A list of potential general milestones or triggers is shown below. Additionally, each individual Transformation contains more specific triggers or milestones that can be used to dictate when a Transformation reaches a new stage.

entries.name: Universal Milestones or Triggers
entries: The following milestones or triggers might cause the beginning of a Transformation, or they may cause a Transformation to move to a new stage.

items: Undertaking an exceptionally evil (or good) act
Being cursed by a dark agent
Being exalted by a patron or god
Making a pact with a powerful fey creature
Stumbling upon an area infused with great power

entries.name: Class Levels and Transformation Stages
entries: While Transformations are milestone- or trigger-based achievements, and come with Flaws ({@book see below|GrimHollowPG24|8|Transformation Boons and Flaws}), Transformations still represent a significant increase in power. For this reason, it is recommended that players and GMs use the Transformation Progression table as a guide for when characters should be able to increase to the next stage of a Transformation.

entries.name: Transformation Boons and Flaws
entries: When the prerequisites for a Transformation are met and the Transformation begins, the character undergoing the Transformation is considered to be at Stage 1 of the Transformation.

At this point, the player should follow the instructions for selecting the Boons and Flaws for Stage 1. For some Transformations, the character may have to choose among various options. Similarly, some Transformations may require a character to select more than one Boon or Flaw at a given stage of Transformation.

data.name: Chapter 7: Spells & Curses
entries: Etharis hosts a menagerie of magical creatures and spellcasters. Ranging from terrifying liches to ancient Primordials, many of these fearsome entities wield immense arcane powers.
Most of the spells detailed here range on the darker side of magic: incantations that drain your blood, tear out your soul, or kill you in other gruesome ways. And then there are the really bad ones.
Included here are two special kinds of spells: Sangromancy spells and Shadowsteel curses. These spell types work similarly to regular spells, but with some subtle differences, noted below.

Shadowsteel curses are unique afflictions that progress in stages over time. At each stage, the afflicted have an opportunity to either shake off the curse's symptoms or suffer worsening effects until the curse reaches its final stage. These curses can only be cast by spellslingers who have access to the rare and dangerous substance known as Shadowsteel.

Sangromancy spells allow casters to use their own blood and life force to push their magic beyond normal limits. The more these casters sacrifice, the more powerful their spells. While some train to reduce the strain of this magic on themselves, others use magical items or spellcasting foci to provide a more efficient path to Sangromancy mastery.
Below is a collection of new spells found within the world of Etharis for players and GMs.

entries.name: Spell List
entries: The following spell list shows the spells each class has access to. A spell's school of magic is noted in parentheses. If a spell can be cast as a {@variantrule Ritual|XPHB}, the Ritual tag also appears in parentheses.
{@i * Denotes a Sangromancy spell}

rows: Bard, Cleric, Druid, Ranger, Warlock, Wizard

entries.name: Shadowsteel Curses
entries: Within Etharis, there are long-lasting spells empowered by a rare substance called Shadowsteel. Shadowsteel channels dark emotions, and spells cast with the substance grow in power as the targets languish under their spiteful effects.

entries.name: Special Training
entries: While Shadowsteel curses aren't restricted by alignment, casting a Shadowsteel curse is considered evil. A Shadowsteel curse is felt by any Celestial or Fiend within 1 mile of its casting. This taint remains with the caster for as long as the target remains cursed.
To cast a Shadowsteel curse requires three facets:

items: A spell slot of a given level.

entries: The caster can increase proficiency with these curses by taking the {@feat Shadowsteel Master|GrimHollowPG24} feat.

entries.name: Components
entries: When casting a Shadowsteel curse, the spellcaster can use special components to enhance the curse. These components are listed in the curse's description. See "{@book Saving Throw Modifications|GrimHollowPG24|9|Saving Throw Modifications}," for more information.

entries.name: Shadowsteel Focus
entries: Casting a Shadowsteel curse requires a {@item Shadowsteel Focus|GrimHollowPG24}—like a typical {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB} but comprised of Shadowsteel. The availability of Shadowsteel should be tailored to how available the GM wishes curses to be. Allowing the {@feat Shadowsteel Adept|GrimHollowPG24} feat means the GM has provided the means to access a Shadowsteel Focus.

entries.name: Casting Range
entries: Shadowsteel curses can only be cast on a creature that the caster has interacted with closely. This requires that the caster be within 60 feet of a target for at least 1 minute. Once this occurs, the caster can target the victim with a curse from anywhere on the same plane of existence.

entries.name: Cost of Casting
entries: Casting a Shadowsteel curse is a draining experience. The caster gains 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level after casting a Shadowsteel curse. For every active Shadowsteel curse, the caster loses 1 {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Point Die}, down to a minimum of 0 {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice}. If the cursed creature is cured or the curse afflicting it reaches Culmination, the caster recovers the {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Point Die} linked to that curse. The lost {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB} don't reduce the caster's {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Hit Point} maximum; the caster simply can't recover or spend {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice}.
Using Curses in a Campaign

Shadowsteel curses are powerful in both their narrative and mechanical resonance. They are designed to have immediate, short-term, and long-term effects. In this way, they are useful for both characters and NPCs.
For use by players, keep the following in mind:

items: Shadowsteel curses often have costly Material components and a cost to the caster's health.

The full power of a Shadowsteel curse is in its long-term effects. Players may not care about inflicting those effects because they want to quickly defeat enemies in combat. Having smart foes flee battles might prompt characters to consider the long-term impact of these curses.

entries: For use against characters, keep the following in mind:

items: Use the slow waxing of a curse over the days or weeks to facilitate story and drama. Emphasize the narrative impacts over the mechanical detriments. Use the curse's mechanics to illustrate and support the narrative.
Finding the components to remove a curse can become a major focus of a campaign. Diagnosing a curse, learning its cure, and then hunting the components for that cure can offer a side or main quest.

entries.name: Spontaneous Curses
entries: While Shadowsteel curses generally require training, the expenditure of a spell slot as with any leveled spell, and a {@item Shadowsteel Focus|GrimHollowPG24}, sometimes these curses can be performed spontaneously under specific, but dramatic, circumstances. The following instances can create a Shadowsteel curse without the {@feat Shadowsteel Adept|GrimHollowPG24} feat, a spell slot, or a Shadowsteel Focus:

items: The dying breath of a betrayed lover.
Breaking a vow sworn in the name of a powerful being.
Betraying a (CR 8+) Celestial, Fey, Fiend, or Undead.
Slaying a powerful figure corrupted by the {@book Aether Kindred|GrimHollowPG24|9|The Aether Kindred}.
Corrupting a person or area of great natural beauty.

entries.name: Saving Throw Modifications
entries: A caster can enhance Shadowsteel curses by adding additional components to the spell. The casting time of the curse, or the relationship between the caster and the target, also changes the power and efficacy of the curse. Use the list below to modify the saving throw or the DC. The modifiers are cumulative:

items: {@b Special Components}. The target has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on the saving throw.
{@b Animosity}. If the target has wronged the caster, it has–2 on the saving throw.
{@b Proximity}. If the caster can see the target, it has–2 on the saving throw.
{@b Quick Cast}. The casting time is Action instead of the normal casting time, but the target has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on the saving throw.

entries.name: Progression of a Shadowsteel Curse
entries: Shadowsteel curses are spells that progress in phases called Stages. Between each stage is an Escalation Check. A Shadowsteel curse uses the following structure:

items.name: Saving Throw
items.entry: The target makes a saving throw against the spell when it is first cast. Even on a successful save, a Shadowsteel curse can cause severe harm.

items.name: Initial Effect
items.entry: This is the effect that occurs when the target fails its first saving throw. The curse is often dormant at this stage, waiting for a trigger to progress.

items.name: Triggering Event
items.entry: A specific event, such as an action or word, causes the curse to awaken. The curse immediately advances to Stage 1.

items.name: Stage 1
items.entry: This stage hints at what is in store for the cursed target. The effects of this stage are usually cosmetic. Daily at dawn, the target makes an Escalation Check to determine if the curse advances to the next stage. Curing the curse at this stage requires {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} or {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB} and one cure component.

items.name: Stage 2
items.entry: Cumulative with the effects of Stage 1. Daily at dawn, the target makes an Escalation Check to determine if the curse advances to the next stage. Curing the curse at this stage requires two spellcasters simultaneously casting Remove Curse or Greater Restoration and two cure components.

items.name: Stage 3
items.entry: Cumulative with the effects of Stage 1 and Stage 2. Daily at dawn, the target makes an Escalation Check to determine if the curse advances to the next stage. Curing the curse at this stage requires three spellcasters simultaneously casting Remove Curse or Greater Restoration and three cure components.

items.name: Culmination
items.entry: When a Shadowsteel curse reaches this stage, the consequences are often dire, fundamentally changing what the target is. The effects from all previous stages end, and only this effect remains. If a player character transforms into a creature from this curse, it becomes an NPC. This can only be cured by a {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell or similar magic.

entries.name: Initial Effect
entries: A Shadowsteel curse often has an immediate effect when first cast but then lies dormant until the target completes a task or action that satisfies the curse's Triggering Event. For example, a creature afflicted with the {@spell Curse of Ravenous Hunger|GrimHollowPG24} suffers minor effects until it consumes its next meal.
If a creature fails its saving throw against Shadowsteel curse, it doesn't know it is cursed unless the specific curse mentions otherwise.

entries.name: Triggering Event
entries: A Shadowsteel curse waits like a trap for a specific trigger called a Triggering Event. A creature doesn't know it is cursed, and doesn't know what the trigger is. Once the Triggering Event occurs, however, the curse immediately progresses to stage 1.

entries.name: Escalation Checks
entries: Escalation represents the curse gaining power as time progresses. Daily at dawn, a cursed creature makes an Escalation Check to see if its curse escalates. This is a {@dice d20} roll with a DC equal to the number of Tests it has made for this specific stage. On a failed Escalation Check, the curse progresses to the next stage.
For example, a creature that just triggered a curse with its Triggering Event makes an Escalation Check daily at dawn.

It must roll higher than a 1. The next day at dawn, the DC increases to 2, and so on. If, on the fifth dawn, it rolls a 5 or less, the curse escalates to stage 2. The creature applies any new effects and resets the DC to 1.

entries.name: Stages of Progression
entries: While Shadowsteel curses are dangerous magic, they take time to reach full power. Curses develop across stages. Whenever a cursed creature fails an Escalation Check, the curse advances to the next stage. The effects of a new stage are in addition to those of previous stages. If an effect contradicts another, use the effect from the greater stage.

entries.name: Culmination
entries: All curses have a Culmination stage. This is the final intent of the curse, and it involves transforming the victim into a twisted creature.

Culminations are truly evil effects and are permanent without the highest form of magic to reverse them. When a creature is at Stage 3 of a Shadowsteel curse and fails an Escalation Check, apply the effects of the curse's Culmination. The effects from Stages 1 to 3 end and the creature no longer makes Escalation Checks. The curse ends and the curse's caster regains its {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Point Die}. Once a curse's Culmination has been reached, it can only be cured with the use of a{@i Wish} spell or similar magic.

entries.name: Curing
entries: Once a Shadowsteel curse is cast, it is notoriously difficult to cure. Many adventurers have fallen to a curse before they were able to gather a cure. As a result, it isn't unheard of for travelling mystics to carry multiple curing ingredients, to sell for exorbitant prices.

To cure a curse, a cursed creature must be targeted with a {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} or {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB} spell once for each stage that the Shadowsteel curse has reached, and each casting must come from a different caster.

In addition, a number of cure components are required equal to the number of stages the curse has escalated to. For example, a curse that has escalated to Stage 3 requires 3 cure components as well as three castings of {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} or {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB} spell—one cure component per casting—from three different spellcasters. All cure components are consumed during the casting.

The following items provide examples of cure components that can be found within the world of Etharis. A GM can include additional components based on the setting's theme, campaign's story, or player creativity:

items: {@b A hag's promise potion.} An elixir with an intentionally confusing name brewed by hags.
{@b A strand of hair from the lost but not found.} The hair can be from the pillow or other possession of a lost person.
{@b A twice-murdered raven}. A raven that has been killed, resurrected, then killed again.
{@b The highest pinecone of a forest.} A spell or ability to create plants can be used at the highest elevation to produce the pinecone.
{@b A clock that runs backwards.} Casting {@spell Slow|XPHB} and {@spell Haste|XPHB} on a timepiece from the Fey realm will cause it to tick backwards.
{@b A black pearl or a pearl touched by death.} A pearl touched by a drowning person or part of a weapon used in a murder.
{@b A book that has never been read.} A manuscript holding a dead language can work as well.
{@b A rose that grows in darkness.} A rose grown in a tomb.
{@b A life willingly given.} Someone willing to be sacrificed to cure the cursed.

entries.name: Curse Descriptions
entries: The following Shadowsteel curses have been sorted alphabetically.

data.name: Chapter 8: Realms of Etharis

entries.name: Part 3: Etharis Lore
entries: The people, places, and groups that comprise the Grim Hollow setting are often reacting to the horrors and challenges that abound in Etharis. In more than a few instances, however, they are adding to the troubles rather than offering solace.

Every region of Grim Hollow, from the vampire-ruled lands of {@book Ostoya|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Ostoyan Empire} to the mist-shrouded and faerie-cursed setting of the {@book Charneault Kingdom|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Charneault Kingdom}, offers fresh challenges for characters trying to survive and bring hope to the downtrodden, threatened, persecuted and haunted.

Every type of dark fantasy story has a place in Etharis. As the descriptions of the regions unfold before you, imagine what life would be like for the common folk in these areas. How are their everyday lives affected by the magical and mundane challenges presented? What part do the rulers or other power groups play in the safety—or the danger—of the population?

Then, more importantly, what can the heroes and adventurers of the realms do to change their situations? A lycanthrope infestation may be blamed for death and ill fortune in a land, but is there a greater threat behind it, one with a source closer to home? As adventurers in Grim Hollow peel back the layers of these threats, they are likely to find that the true peril is not in the supernatural, but in the machinations of the people trying to hold on to power.

Part of this longing and need for power manifests in the form of factions or power groups. People band together, for better or worse, to achieve a level of power they would otherwise be unable to achieve. With great power, however, comes the tendency to misuse that power.

Trade guilds, merchant groups, arcane organizations, or secret societies—all of them operate on the principle that combined might swings with more leverage than an individual can. But any organization, regardless of how noble its intentions, can be corrupted by the whims or shortcomings of just a few individuals, or even a single one.

Behind all of this corruption is the magic that infuses Etharis. The forces of fiends, angels, spirits, and formless horrors pulse and swirl in the very air that brings life to Grim Hollow. That magic, like combined might, can be used for good or evil, depending on the wishes of the wielders. But that magic is often just as corrupting as any other powerful force.
As you will come to find out, the history of Etharis is a history not unlike our own. Without the guidance and understanding of noble, wise individuals, it can quickly become dark and violent.
{@i Welcome, adventurers, to Etharis.}

{@i I would rather you had arrived here at a happier time, when civilization was still at its height, when there were still gods who watched over this land's denizens. Those days are long past, and we all must somehow carry on.}

{@i Etharis has changed. It is a land haunted by restless dead and unspeakable monstrosities. Its people have grown colder, insular, superstitious, partial to violence and murder. I cannot say it is a good time for adventurers, so I share this guide to help you find your bearings faster in Etharis and increase your chance of survival. Know that some of the writers have paid great personal costs to acquire their knowledge. I hope you will put what you find here to good use}.

{@i Perhaps you are destined for greatness. Or perhaps you will very quickly know the number of your days. Etharis will test your mettle. Regardless, I pray you will live an interesting and worthy life, that I may one day record your exploits in my journals}.
{@i May you thrive here, adventurers. Till we meet in brighter times.}
—Odis Tremain, Historian of Sarmar Academy

The world of Etharis, like most worlds, is divided into nations. These political entities give stability to the world, while at the same time posing threats—sometimes to one another, and sometimes to their own citizens. A campaign set primarily in one nation or another differs in tone or content to a campaign set elsewhere in Etharis. Likewise, a campaign that sees characters traveling between nations taps into the different styles of play and themes.

The nations and city-states of Grim Hollow all have their own threats to contend with: some manifestation of the corrupting power of the supernatural influencing their lives. There are threats also caused by mortals' inhumanity toward other mortals.

Between the threats of the supernatural and the threats of the evils done by mortal beings, every type of story can be told within the realms that make up the world of Grim Hollow. The juxtaposition of these tales holds a great deal of narrative power. Mortal evildoers try to blame the consequences of their acts on supernatural forces to draw attention away from themselves. Conversely, what at first glance appears to be atrocities committed by a person, are very likely to be the result of magic or immortal creatures coming into contact with innocent victims.

entries.name: Isolation and Travel
entries: Travel between nations is difficult but not impossible. Natural barriers between the nations—mountain ranges, forests, water, etc.—mean that only deliberate and costly means of travel see people interacting. Even when no natural barriers exist along nations' borders, social ones are just as easily constructed.

The lack of international trade and travel means that social and cultural exchanges are infrequent. This leads to a form of nationalism in most nations that is hard to breach with common sense and empathy. Villages that might otherwise be neighborly may exchange hostilities over different religious practices, when both places are actually worshipping the same Arch Seraph in a very similar manner.

In game and story terms, travelers entering a new town are likely treated as suspicious until they have proven themselves friendly—and even then, locals are quick to turn on them if it's convenient to blame them for unexplained troubles. Conniving and murderous folks in one town may worship an Arch Seraph, and truly kind and generous folks in another town might revere a more benign aspect of an Arch Daemon.

entries.name: The Dangers of the Dark Wilderness
entries: While no city, town, or stronghold is safe—because so-called "civilized folks" can be just as dangerous as the monsters—more risk definitely lies in wait in the wilderness between towns, cities, and villages. Each region boasts its own special variety of wilderness threat. Wandering fey roam the untamed lands in {@book Charneault|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Charneault Kingdom}. {@book Valika|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Valikan Clans} has seen a recent rise in undead because of the Coldfire Crisis. The mutated beasts of {@book Bürach|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Bürach Empire} leave little time for weary travelers to rest, even on the most well-maintained roads.

Because of the dangers of travel, merchants and others whose careers are reliant on moving from place to place often band together to form caravans. Sometimes this practice has saved lives. Other times the mass graves they are buried in just need to be deeper and wider.

What the dangers mean most for adventurers is that rest comes at a premium. It is impossible to get a decent night's sleep on the road. Only the comfortable beds of an inn secured behind sturdy walls and an armed militia are sure to provide the rest needed to recover from hard days fighting monsters.
Languages in Etharis

Languages in Etharis divided the world as much as political borders do. The common citizenry of Etharis speak the tongue of their nations, and rarely anything else. Only those who travel extensively have the need or the means to speak a language other than that of their village and their neighbors.

The species have their own language as well, but even then they're only learned and spoken if they're the predominant language in an area. Established dwarven families in one of the nations like Ostoya, for example, may never speak Dwarven, favoring Ostoy instead.
Hubs of homogenous species within a nation, however, speak both the heritage's tongue and the national language.

Since there is no common language that unites the civilized world, translators are highly valued and respected. Adventurers, as well as those who make a living by moving from place to place, often take the time to learn as many languages as they can.
The following languages are most used in Etharis:

items.name: Charneault:
items.entry: The dominant language of the Charneault Kingdom.

items.name: Castinellan:
items.entry: The dominant language of the Castinellan Provinces. This language is also used for most of Etharis's religious texts. Until recently it was considered a crime to translate the teachings of the Arch Seraphs into a language other than Castinellan. Castinellan is also predominantly spoken in Morencia, making it the most common language used in trade.

items.name: Valiki:
items.entry: The dominant language of the Valikan Clans. Each of the clans speaks a slightly different dialect of Valiki, but each dialect is similar enough to make themselves understood.

items.name: Low Bürach:
items.entry: The commoner's dialect in the Bürach Empire. It is more heavily accented than High Bürach, making the general population of the nation harder for foreigners to understand.

items.name: Higher Bürach:
items.entry: The highborn dialect in the Bürach Empire. Most formal writings are in this dialect as well, such as religious texts, laws, royal decrees, plays and poems, etc. If a foreigner learns Bürach, this is the dialect they learn.

entries: I've not seen a merchant or sailor that doesn't speak most languages. With the sailors, they only know the curses though.

entries.name: The Bürach Empire
entries: The Bürach Empire is a land of ambition, politics, and a rotting at its core. The Hearthkeepers of the Bürach attempt to keep the political center of the empire stable, often by means that range from subtle to nefariously violent. The four regions that comprise Bürach have their own issues and their own structures, but they share one truth: the world is collapsing.

The empire still has an ambition that its might can no longer support, which only serves to fuel the flames of grim, and ultimately futile, determination. However, the vast continent and foreboding barriers like the mountainous Grey Spines make keeping the empire together impossible.

From the ashes of what remains of the empire's most glorious days, echoes of its past victories ring out as its end draws near. In the wake of its impending fate, this plagued lion is determined not to fade silently into obscurity.

entries.name: United by Faith
entries: Bürach was born in the Era of Expansion. The smaller kingdoms and tribes of central Etharis first became united by their faith in the Four Divines: Aurelia, Galt, Ulmyr, and Maligant. This pantheon chose Emperor Indorius I to begin forging a new empire.

To aid in his task of unifying the realms, Emperor Indorius I received four gifts filled with the divine power of each of the gods: {@i Aurelia's Hearthfire Breastplate}, Galt's Circlet known as {@i Indorius's Crown}, {@i Ulmyr's Eye}, and {@i Dämglesvir}, the Might of Heaven, Maligant's Sword.

With these blessings laid down by the heavens upon the Bürach Empire's gleaming fate, Indorius I led one conquest after another. Independent regions fell in line as the empire marched, slaughtered, negotiated, and conquered neighboring territories. With their bold momentum, they saw fit to unite the world and stamp out their foes. For the glory of the Four Divines, the provinces put their faith in the emperor's leadership and confidence.

entries.name: Gods' End
entries: The Hearthkeepers, a council of advisors and divine soothsayers, enacted the Edict of Eternal Blood, which decreed that only the emperor's direct descendants could lead Bürach. The effects of royal inbreeding were inevitable over the decades.

Leopold I proved to be an impatient and cruel child. He would imprison or torture servants and subjects for even minor infractions. He insisted on executions at noble feasts, as if the executioners were minstrels performing for his guests. The cruelty and perversity of the new Emperor corrupted more than his subjects and holdings. They changed the very nature of the four Sacred Artifacts—and by extension, the four gods themselves.

Leopold I was assassinated, but the damage had already been done. In the wake of the corruption of the gods, wholesale war broke out between them, and between the regions where their worship was favored. In one generation, the might of the Bürach Empire shattered.

entries.name: Aftermath
entries: In the wake of the Gods' End, every region of the Bürach Empire faces hardships threatening to crumble their greatest achievements and cripple their hopes of better days to come.

The Hearthkeepers attempted to keep the realm together, but civil war created divisions that could not be healed. Border disputes have become more frequent, folk have grown paranoid, and travelers are often greeted with hostility.

Furthermore, the true Sacred Artifacts that had protected the realm and been a symbol of the emperor's divine right of rule went missing. After absconding with them from the Imperial palace, Leopold I's assassins intended to bring the Artifacts to Nordenland. They hoped the wizards could reverse whatever eldritch corruption had overtaken them. They never reached their intended destination.

entries.name: The Great Beast
entries: With the absence of the gods, a new force of dread now stalks the lands of the Bürach Empire, a powerful and corrupting presence that spreads through the realm like rot within an apple. Where it wanders, death follows. Hearts are poisoned, and minds are turned to wickedness. No commoner dares even whisper its name; such is the fear of this rising shadow.

Aberrations have appeared in its wake. The forests of Abendland are filled with many-limbed mutants, their flesh twisted into tortured shapes. They attack wayfarers and set upon villages. Nordenland is plagued by corrupted flora, including trees with human limbs and faces instead of knot holes and branches. Wolfen-headed monsters prowl the hills of Rauland, leaving settlements abandoned wherever they roam. Unterland has reported sightings of corrupted warriors. Their armor is melted into their flesh. Their weapons are extensions of their limbs, and they hunt from place to place, killing indiscriminately.

The sigil of this horror has been found scrawled on church doors and in basements—a deer skull crowned with many antlers. There are no survivor accounts—at least none that can be trusted. It's described as a behemoth wreathed in shadows, whose body is that of a rotting corpse and whose bony crown rakes through the clouds. Its trumpeting shriek transforms people into monsters. None know what it is.
It has no other name than "the Great Beast."

entries.name: Provinces
entries: The mighty Bürach Empire is comprised of four provinces: {@book Abendland|GrimHollowPG24|8|Abendland} as its heart, {@book Nordenland|GrimHollowPG24|8|Nordenland} as its mind, {@book Rauland|GrimHollowPG24|8|Rauland} holds a pickaxe, and {@book Unterland|GrimHollowPG24|8|Unterland} carries a sword.

Each province began as its own unique kingdom or culture. The natural resources of Abendland's fertile woods made them a mercantile kingdom of great wealth and influence. Magic and philosophy defined the complex cultures of Nordenland. Rauland was a land of builders who resisted conquest through technology. Meanwhile, the proud Unterfolk keep a long military tradition stretching deep into their history as warring tribes.

At the empire's height, the provinces worked in harmony for the sake of the Bürach's bright future. Yet the empire has never been homogeneous. In the wake of the Gods' End, the cultural divides between the provinces have only grown deeper, and mutual prosperity has given way to fear and self-interest.

entries.name: Abendland
entries: Abendland is where Aurelia, Goddess of protection, healing, and the hearth, found worship. It is also where the holy church of the Hearthkeepers began. According to scripture, Aurelia instructed her first priestess, Amara, to strike the ground with a spear, from which a wellspring of water emerged. This spring swelled into the blessed Lake Osea, which fed the surrounding land until it grew into a verdant forest. The city of Altenheim was built upon Lake Osea's southern bank, and from its cathedral, the Hearthkeepers spread their holy message.

Abendland is rich in farmland and timber, but its most valuable commodity has always been religion. Scripture marks the province as the birthplace of Indorius I. With such a blessed history and divine authority, the Hearthkeepers controlled the fates of many who sought the favor of the gods.

Self-appointed and defiant of church authority, the Säullan Council comprises powerful leaders from each of the empire's provinces. Though far from politically united, the council negotiates trade and resources between the provinces to deal with the empire's many troubles. Once the young Emperor Odalric I grew into his station, the Säullan Council began serving as close advisors and soon superseded the Hearthkeepers as the emperor's most trusted aides.

Meanwhile, tensions within the Hearthkeepers rise. Many feel Pope Murrich no longer commands the influence over the throne he once did. For this reason, the church quietly searches for Murrich's successor while it waits for his death—timely or otherwise.

entries.name: Emperor Odalric Pongor Aurelius I
entries: Practically coronated in the womb, no other child's birth was more anticipated than Odalric I. The babe knew nothing of his father, Aratron II, and was raised by his mother Valeria and Pope Murrich. Throughout his life, the empress and the pope would hover over him in desperate attempts to mold his mind.

However, once introduced to the Säullan Council, Odalric I became fascinated by learning about the world outside Altenheim. He desires to understand the threats facing his empire. Odalric I spends long hours questioning members of the Säullan Council, learning economics, strategy, production, and philosophy.

entries.name: Nordenland
entries: Nordenland is old. Its living cultures predate recorded history. The land is rich with the spark of magic, entwining Norden traditions with arcane practices and spiritual communing. The people of Nordenland have less fear of magic than other Bürach citizens. Their leaders have weaved the power of the arcane since the god Ulmyr first taught them how to grasp it.

Diversity runs through the cultures of Nordenland. While folk who reside in the west hew to the Bürach Empire and its traditions, the further north and east one travels, the closer the Norden begin to resemble their Valikan neighbors.

When Emperor Indorius I was crowned, Ulmyr became part of a united pantheon. Many Norden followed the wisdom of their deity, and Nordenland became a province of the growing Bürach Empire. Yet the eastern settlements preferred their own ancient ways to the laws of a foreign power, resisting the absorption of their territory.

The Raulfolk came to harvest timber and metal for their workshops, logging the forests and cutting open the earth. The Hearthkeepers came to spread their religion, chasing away the primal spirits the Norden communed with. Soldiers from Unterland arrived to enforce the empire's laws and tithes. The east Norden fought for a time, but as they were outnumbered, they eventually had to accept the empire's embrace. Their simmering anger never waned.

In the aftermath of the Gods' End, the Eastern Norden have abandoned their oaths to the Bürach Empire and reverted to their old traditions. They live closer to nature, refusing to fell living trees or lift stones without first beseeching the primal spirits to which their ancestors spoke.

Nordenland has long been the focal point of magical studies in the Bürach Empire. The regional capital of {@book Erlefurt|GrimHollowPG24|9|Erlefurt Colleges} began as a mage college. The wizards and sorcerers trained and educated through its long history have advised emperors and reshaped battlefields. Its reputation as a place of enlightenment and astounding knowledge is also tempered by a cautious approach to the dangers of magic.

By contrast, the druids of Eastern Nordenland are viewed with contempt by the empire. The Order of the Golden Bough is a druidic circle who practice the old ways of their ancient peoples—rumored to be pact makers and heretics. The Golden Bough are scattered across small settlements deep in the wilderness of Eastern Nordenland.

entries.name: Archduchess Maelfa Erlekind
entries: The last heir to the founding house of Erlefurt, Archduchess Maelfa, is an assertive leader who has never once bowed to an emperor. Nevertheless, the Bürach Empire accepts her as ruler of Nordenland. The Duchess achieves her autonomy through diplomacy, understanding that trusted mages are too valuable for the empire to risk alienating Nordenland.

Maelfa has the love of her people and the respect of the mage colleges, enabling her bold leadership. Rumors circulate that Maelfa may also have the support of the {@book Thaumaturge|GrimHollowPG24|10|The Thaumaturge}—a secretive cabal of powerful beings said to control global politics from the shadows.

entries.name: Rauland
entries: Rauland is a place said to have been crafted by the hands of Galt himself. As such, those born to the province are taught from a young age the nobility of labor and self-reliance. This is the core of Rauland's culture. Rauland began as a collection of dwarven and gnomish fiefdoms in the southernmost reach of central Etharis. Their territories spread from the Rock-Teeth Mountains to the north and east as far as the Grey Spine.

For generations, the Raulfolk tinkered in their mountain halls. They forged weapons and jewelry of breathtaking beauty. They built the mountain cities of Stehlenwald and Grabenstein—feats of architecture and engineering unrivalled throughout Etharis. Carved from granite and marble, Stehlenwald resembles a celestial stairway ascending the mountainside toward the heavens. The Quartz Palace that crowns the city remains one of the wonders of the Bürach Empire.

Bürach came to rely on the craftsmanship of the Raulfolk. Thousands came to Raulish guilds to learn carpentry, smithing, architecture, and construction. The forge fires of Stehlenwald burned ceaselessly to fill the need for the weapons and tools required by a growing empire. In every realm the Bürach Empire has ruled, the touchmarks of Raulish artisans are found.

After the events of Gods' End, Rauland was a husk. Its people were exhausted. Its resources were spent. Though it remains the industrial epicenter of the Bürach Empire, it relies more on metals from Unterland and timber from Nordenland for its production. This has weakened Rauland's borders and reduced the quality of their craftsmanship to an echo of its former glory.

entries.name: Archduke Ulrich Eizenherz
entries: The dwarven lord of Rauland, Archduke Eizenherz, was fair minded, organized, and well loved in his younger years. Then age and strife tainted his mind with fear and paranoia.

The Archduke has since become reclusive. Despite being a picture of quiet dignity while in public, a crippling terror of the dark fills him privately. He goes nowhere without a light, even when he sleeps. Rumors swirl that Eizenherz sees the eyes of the {@book Great Beast|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Great Beast} in his dreams. The abhorrent horror whispers secrets to him, though what they contain he shares with no one.

entries.name: Unterland
entries: Unterland's history dates back to warring tribes of hunters who lived in the marshlands and mountains of the Eastern Bürach Empire. For generations, they fought among themselves. Minor kings quibbled for territory while warlords and monsters conquered their lands. Some tribes collapsed; others united. Eventually, it was the Unterfolk who rose from the lion's den as the strongest among them.

Worshipping the war god Maligant, the Unters chose their generals for their strength and cunning. They forged strong alliances but also knew when to sacrifice allies for victory. They learned to wage war with surgical precision instead of relying on brute force—to break their enemies' spirit as well as their armies.

Favored by Maligant, the Unters even managed to capture Grabenstein—a feat many tribes failed to achieve during the Era of Expansion. The dwarven fortress fell to siege engines designed by Maligant's priests, and the crumbling remnants of the walls are still visible in the city to this day.

In the regional capital of Olstenburg, Unterland tries to rebuild its strength. Here, the Academy of Swords dates back to Maligant's earliest teachings in warfare. Every able-bodied youth is sent to the Academy for two years of training and military service, helping Unterland maintain its standing army. Yet soldiers are needed in every province. The most talented recruits are sent into battle as quickly as new ones can be trained.

The Academy of Swords produces infantry composed of pikemen, swordsmen, and archers. The strongest youths or noble heirs may be chosen to become heavy cavalry. The Academy also trains scouts and rangers, sometimes in forts hidden deep in the wilderness of Unterland, where their skills are best sharpened.

With shadows rising inside the Bürach Empire, another type of military school has also emerged, those that train monster hunters. The old strategies used to repel armies are not always effective against swarming monstrosities—particularly those spread by the wandering of the Great Beast. Though {@book monster hunter guilds|GrimHollowPG24|10|Monster Hunter Guilds} are not always sanctioned in Unterland due to their mercenary reputations, the teachings of Maligant certainly encouraged cunning methods of warfare like those employed in the hunting trade.

entries.name: Lord General Vassily Roemer
entries: A beloved figure of both martial prowess and diplomacy, Lord General Roemer is widely recognized for his strategic mind and honorable bearing. He was appointed to the Säullan Council for his loyalty to the empire. His dedication to protecting his realms is unquestioned.
