Though one wary eye watches the shadow of Ostoya, Roemer is forced to divert troops elsewhere to deal with threats across the provinces. With never enough troops or resources, the Lord General relies on mercenaries more than he'd like.

entries.name: The Ostoyan Empire
entries: East of the Grey Spine peaks lies a land cloaked in eternal night. The sun itself has forsaken this place. The Ostoyan Empire is a realm as cold and grim as the folk who live there, ever sheltering in their homes from the deathless monsters that prowl the dark. Or worse, the dreaded nobility themselves.

{@book The Crimson Court|GrimHollowPG24|10|The Crimson Court} rules the empire, a cabal of seven vampires who govern Ostoya's provinces. Domineering, wealthy, and ruthless, the Court exacts a blood tax upon its mortal citizens in return for the vampires' leadership and protection. Their strength deters invasion from the Bürach Empire. Yet the Court are far from allies, constantly conspiring against each other while they all hunger to sit at the head of the table.

Whilst the Crimson Court plot, their own progeny and other undying horrors stalk across the empire. Corpses become restless when buried in Ostoya's soil. Souls linger long after they've perished. Heroes are rare, as the few capable of fighting such evil are either slaughtered by the Court or enticed by their wealth and power. Until the sun returns, Ostoya shall remain a realm haunted by death and despair.

entries.name: The Darkfall
entries: The land of Ostoya has not always been shrouded in night. It had once been splendorous, a wilderness of untapped bounties that could provide everything a burgeoning empire required. Then, everything changed.

During the Second Bürach-Ostoyan war, when the western empire tried once more to subsume its neighbor, the realm was shaken by a calamitous earthquake. The earth was rent with fissures. Darkness crept across the land. And as if it were made of liquid gold, the sun melted from the sky to never be seen again.

Then the undead came. It was as if the Netherworld had been opened and was emptying itself of corpses. Slavering ghouls, skeletal regiments, and howling spirits rushed forth at the ends of their masters' strings. The lords of undeath. The vampires.
I know a couple of elves who claim to have been at the Darkfall. I know they're lying though, because they're alive.

entries.name: Rise of the Crimson Court
entries: The old aristocracy of the Ostoyan Empire reacted to this crisis by sending soldiers into the gaping fissures at Nov Ostoya, the nation's capital. They hoped to stem the tide of undeath and learn what curse had plunged the empire into its enduring night. Instead, these souls were corrupted by the sanguine curse. They returned to the surface under the thrall of those who had slept for centuries, until awoken by the Darkfall. Freed at last, these vampires began turning or slaughtering the leaders of Ostoya, making the empire their own.

The lords of undeath threw back the Büracher invaders, seized Ostoya's resources, and installed one among themselves to rule over each Ostoyan province. They rewarded mortals who showed loyalty. They granted those of exceptional skill the immortal gift. Any folk who showed defiance or cowardice were claimed as the beginning of the blood tax.

Far from mindless devourers, the vampires who formed the Crimson Court dressed themselves as nobility and installed the structures of their sovereignty. Though they are appetites made flesh, what they truly crave is power.

Currently, the Crimson Court is ruled by Grand Duke Drago Koshevek, the most ancient and feared among their number. The remaining six members change through the years. They might be staked by courageous vampire hunters, assassinated by an ambitious underling, or the victim of a plot enacted by one of their fellow courtiers.

entries.name: The Land
entries: {@book The Darkfall|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Darkfall} transformed Ostoya from a realm of plenty into a land of eternal dusk. Crops are nigh impossible to grow in the cold soil. Livestock is difficult to raise and protect from predators prowling the countryside, especially as some are now undead monsters who prey on beasts or mortals alike.

The people of Ostoya tend to be poor, scratching together a small enough living just to stay alive. They never leave their homes needlessly. Folk that must travel do so in large groups or with armed escorts as best they can, always sticking to the road, whether wayfaring through Ostoya's midnight forests, gurgling swamps, shadowy mountains, or drifting along its rivers.

The land outside settlements tends to be as quiet as the dead of night. The darkness is occasionally pierced by the howl of a wolf, the chittering of bats, or cries for help from within the gloom. One should never rush to aid. Ostoyans never speak to strangers on the road. If a large hole is discovered descending deep into the earth, it's always best to leave it be and never venture inside.

Even the weather in Ostoya brings death. Rain can be nearly constant, and without sun, the air is rarely warm. Sickness festers in such conditions. Mud clings to the boots and clothes. In the empire's northern reaches, drifting snow is common for at least half the year. In the south, a cold mist snakes into valleys, woods, and villages, lingering without the heat of day to dissipate it.

The commonfolk see the sun only in their dreams. Very few people alive today remember its warmth on their skin. The children of Ostoya can't even imagine its brightness, describing it to one another as a flickering campfire in the sky.

entries.name: Rivers
entries: The rivers that flow through Ostoya are the lifeblood of its merchants and trade. These coiling veins rapidly ferry wares and resources between settlements and make travel through certain regions far quicker.

Many Ostoyans live their lives on the water. Fishing is a reliable food source when a lack of sunlight makes other forms of agriculture difficult. Some folk make a living ferrying wayfarers or merchandise to other parts of the realm, including villagers with a simple raft and pole, and boat captains with entire crews and a cargo hold.

Lake Iorta is south of Fallowheart and feeds most major rivers that snake through Ostoya, connecting all the regional capitals that the Crimson Court command. At Nov Ostoya, the Black Bay sees a tremendous amount of naval trade, even with other realms. Many citizens in Nov Ostoya are employed as sailors or soldiers in Ostoya's grand fleet, or as whalers who harvest valuable meat and oil.

entries.name: The City Below
entries: When the Darkfall cracked open the surface of Ostoya, it revealed a depthless labyrinth of tenebrous boulevards and ruined buildings. Crushed temples. Shattered statues of now nameless idols. Forgotten languages etched into the stonework beneath illustrative and gothic murals, depicting long-forgotten histories. An entire civilization buried in the earth until the moment Ostoya was plunged into darkness, as if the shadows of that place had escaped to envelop the world.

Now called the City Below, this necropolis had been the tomb of the Crimson Court and their progenitors. It remains a pit of undeath. Folk who disappear from Ostoya's provinces are often dragged into the necropolis by some horror which crawled its way out. Explorers are drawn into the City Below by promises of forbidden secrets or stygian treasures.

entries.name: Provinces
entries: The Ostoyan Empire is divided into six provinces, each ruled by one of the six lesser members of the Crimson Court. {@book Soma|GrimHollowPG24|8|Soma}, {@book Raevo|GrimHollowPG24|8|Raevo}, {@book Estspine|GrimHollowPG24|8|Estspine}, {@book Terinima|GrimHollowPG24|8|Terinima}, {@book Bezcodru|GrimHollowPG24|8|Bezcodru}, and {@book Umbroi|GrimHollowPG24|8|Umbroi} are summarized below.

entries.name: Soma
entries: The southernmost province of the empire is entirely enthralled within the Crimson Court's power. Its population includes affluent and sycophantic aristocrats who prostrate themselves to the Court's authority. They hope for some measure of favor, or even a morsel of their rulers' accursed blood. Beneath them are the impoverished and desperate. Folk who fight among themselves for the scraps thrown to them from the high table.

Fissures that extend into the City Below scar the surface of Soma, rippling out from the capital. Yet here the people are least able to defend themselves. Heroes are rare and unwelcome this far south, where they might be perceived as a threat to the Crimson Court. Instead, the commoners must rely on warlocks and soldiers who accept the vampires' patronage in exchange for protecting the mortal livestock.

entries.name: Nov Ostoya
entries: Nov Ostoya is the largest city in the empire, the focus of Ostoya's wealth, and the place from where the Crimson Court projects its sovereignty.

It's known as the City of Gargoyles for its countless menacing statues. The streets are divided into districts, separating the poverty and gang members of the Low Streets from the debaucherous splendor of the Crimson Heights. Blood and coin are both of equal value in Nov Ostoya.
The city is built above the Black Bay. Much of its wealth is drained from the empire's provinces and traded with foreign lands. Little of that coin trickles back to the commonfolk.

entries.name: Grand Duke Drago Koshevek
entries: The most powerful member of the Crimson Court, Grand Duke Drago is viewed as harsh, humorless, and cruel, even by the vampire nobility. His appetite for power and blood is ceaseless. He has led many war hosts but has thus far avoided invading Raevo, perhaps because he detests mortal magic and the {@book Ravencourt Sanctuary|GrimHollowPG24|6|Ravencourt Sanctuary}.

entries.name: Countess Katalin Vulpescu
entries: Alluring and flamboyant, the Countess is the exact opposite of the Grand Duke. She is infamous for hosting lavish and debauched parties, where she plays the part of a glamorous and humble patron but uses her network of informants to gather secrets. She skillfully uses this knowledge to discreetly manipulate events across Ostoya.

entries.name: Raevo
entries: Raevo is the northernmost province of Ostoya, as far within the empire from the Crimson Court's power as possible. The people of Raevo reject the Courts' bloodthirst and tyranny. Having declared themselves in open rebellion, the Raevan leadership aspire to free their southern kin from the vampires' taloned clutches.

The people of Raevo are tenacious. Their righteous hatred of the undead extends to any of their countryfolk who serve or aid the Crimson Court, who they admonish as cowards and traitors. Even Raevo's funeral traditions have devolved into desecrations of the departed. Raevans would prefer to behead and burn their loved ones than see them raised as a living corpse in service to a vampire or necromancer.

The capital of the province is Castalore, a fortified city which coils up the sides of a cliff like a massive serpent. Its high stone walls separate the layered districts. Whilst the lower levels belong to the mud and soldiers of Raevo's standing army, the higher tiers of the city belong to the magocracy.

entries.name: The Magocracy
entries: Unlike many other places in Etharis, magical talent is encouraged and cultivated in Raevo. A dozen tiny institutes of arcane learning crown Castalore's upper districts, under the watchful gaze of the Council of Mages. These imperious wizards govern Raevo. They also seek out individuals of arcane talent, preparing them for possible summons to the {@book Ravencourt Sanctuary|GrimHollowPG24|6|Ravencourt Sanctuary}.

Miles from the Raevan coastline is an island ever shrouded in a blanket of fog. No boat can make the journey there without invitation. Upon the island is the Ravencourt Sanctuary, the most preeminent and secretive academy of magical learning Etharis has known. The mages who've returned from the island exhibit incredible power. Unfortunately, only ten pupils are accepted every seven years, bidden to the island via a mysterious letter—only nine return.

entries.name: Mina Taliesin, the Lady of Masks
entries: Lady Mina Taliesin has been First Minister for decades, using an expansive spy network to warn of dangers to her government. She remains a mystery to most, concealing her face behind a decorative mask that is believed to cover the scars left by a failed assassination. She is driven to destroy Ostoya's vampire aristocracy, but is cautious, not wishing to trade the Crimson Court for conquest by the Bürach Empire.

entries.name: Order of Dawn
entries: The {@book Order of Dawn|GrimHollowPG24|10|Order of Dawn} are Raevo's sword against the Crimson Court. A fellowship of knights, clerics, monster hunters, and spies, the Order are resolute in their purpose. Purge the undead. Punish the guilty. Do not rest until Ostoya is free. Their righteous cause attracts many Raevans to join their ranks, yet their unyielding zealotry drives others away.

entries.name: General Artemios Dulka
entries: Leader of the Order of Dawn, Artemios Dulka, has fought the vampires since he was a boy. He now trains recruits more than he fights, but his passion to liberate the land from vampiric control has not diminished in the least.

entries.name: Estspine
entries: War looms over Estspine like a storm cloud threatening to break. The province is eternally trapped between the war machine of the Bürach Empire to the west and the civil unrest fueled by tensions between Soma and Raevo.

Fallowheart is a symbolic city, and Estspine an important province. The region is home to the first migrants who fled Büracher oppression and settled the lands that would become the Ostoyan Empire. Time and again, Ostoyans have fought for their freedom in Estspine. The Elian Pass through the Grey Spine is the only one wide enough for Büracher armies to march.

The commonfolk of Fallowheart are divided in their loyalties. Some hold that their ancestors did not sacrifice their lives to defeat the Bürach Empire only for future generations to be ruled by a different form of tyranny. One of darkness and bloodshed. Yet others maintain it is only with the strength of the Crimson Court that Ostoya has remained independent of the west.
The region is riddled with secret wars and intrigues, both sides aware that an open conflict could invite the Bürach Empire to invade.

entries.name: Viscount Langkirk Warlow
entries: Ugly and insecure, Viscount Warlow has no sense of noble decorum, horrifically devouring anyone who dares comment on his bad behavior. Whispers say the Grand Duke chose Viscount Warlow to rule Fallowheart because he could be easily manipulated, or because he wanted an excuse to destroy Warlow when he eventually fails at his task.
Fallowheart is a city constantly at war, and nary a drop of blood is spilled. The tension kills though."

entries.name: Terinima
entries: Terinima is the heartland of the Ostoyan Empire. In times before the Darkfall, it was a great plain of arable farmland flanked by forests on its east and west, and fed by the Great Arteriyan River, which flows through Terinima's center. It was a food bowl for the rest of the empire, until the day the sun melted from the sky.

Terinima remains of great importance to Ostoya and the Crimson Court. The province still scratches out whatever produce it can to feed the population, which is a vital step for the vampires to maintain their own source of sustenance. Terinimans are earthy folk with few ambitions besides selling whatever meagre crop they've managed to grow and keeping their families safe. When the call to rebellion or adventure is thrust upon them, usually due to tragedy or circumstance, they leave for Raevo or Soma, usually via Crowsbend.

The Teriniman capital is a crowded market town. Skilled workers such as blacksmiths, cobblers, herbalists, and scribes are more likely to find employment here. Deckhands and merchants are also common in Crowsbend, frequently coming and going from other settlements.

entries.name: Countess Augustine Vasinesca
entries: Known by most as the "Blood Sommelier," Vasinesca can sniff out mortals with the most decadent-tasting blood. This talent has made her popular among the Crimson Court.

entries.name: Bezcodru
entries: Bezcodru is the domain of flesh hungering ghouls, wayward spirits, and hunting packs of terrifying vampire-werewolf hybrids known as fzeg. All these monsters and more lurk within the tangled depths of the Stillborn Forest. Bezcodru's borders begin and end at the eaves of the forest's gnarled and pale trees. Not even the light of the moon makes it beneath the canopy, except in silvery beams on particularly clear nights, which only deepen the shadows where horrors hide within.

Lumber and ore are the two things this province produces the most. The commonfolk are worked mercilessly to ensure these commodities feed the Crimson Court's demands, and when either is lacking, the value is made up by the blood tax instead.

Bezcodrans tend to look out only for themselves. Their eyes constantly dart towards the shadows. Most are miners, loggers, fishers, or couriers who transport the region's wealth along twisted forest roads or black-water rivers. Mercenaries and monster hunters are in high demand as escorts through the dangerous woods, but it's a dangerous trade. The local Court member is likely to take offence if their kindred are stopped from feeding wherever they will.

entries.name: Baron Mihael, The Wolf
entries: Prone towards the habits of lycanthropy, the Baron rules through violence more than any other Court member, but he richly rewards loyal servants. Baron Mihael has killed many failed usurpers of the Grand Duke, which is one of the reasons why Koshevek so greatly favors him. He's razed villages sheltering rebel sympathizers and slaughtered vampire hunters who've dared travel south of Raevo. All of Ostoya fears The Wolf.

entries.name: Umbroi
entries: Umbroi is a vast stretch of festering swampland along Ostoya's eastern coastline. Most folk simply call it the Black Mire. The region reeks of decay from the corpses trapped in the mud and brackish waters, many of which animate to try to claw the living down into the muck with them. Insects buzz ceaselessly. Fungi fill the air with toxic spores.

Few inhabit the Black Mire, except perhaps spies and rangers who use the bog to travel unseen. Reclusive druids may feel an affinity for this land, despite its repulsiveness. Hag covens and their warlocks are rumored to make their homes at the rotted heart of Umbroi, scheming their machinations against both Soma and Raevo.

Riven is the largest settlement in Umbroi at the southern edge of the Black Mire. Even so, the village is tiny. Anything built upon the swamp is inevitably swallowed, and so Riven slowly collapses and is rebuilt until the village is nearly unrecognizable within a few years.

The villagers in Riven are quiet and superstitious. They seem to fear their own countryfolk, the Umbroians, who make their homes deeper in the Mire away from civilization. These strange individuals have learned to navigate the swamps using small boats and hidden water channels. They can be paid in coin to escort travelers through, yet some in Riven warn against it. Such folk have sinister senses of humor and appear to revel in others' fear.

entries.name: Marchioness Iulia Cutov
entries: Quiet and ruthless, the Marchioness Iulia Cutov has grand ambitions that she keeps secret. She spends very little time in the Black Mire, instead commanding a fleet to protect Ostoya's coastline and advising the Grand Duke on issues of naval power and seabound trade. She also guards the bog against Raevan spies from infiltrating into Ostoya. A few whispers suggest she secretly parleys with groups outside the Crimson Court, but no one can say with whom and for what purpose.

entries.name: The Charneault Kingdom
entries: Unfolding in the southwestern corner of Etharis, beneath the rugged Rock-Teeth Mountains and the dense forest known as the Grove Maze, Charneault is renowned for its meandering hills, vast sky, and clear rivers. It's said that the residents of Charneault, both the elves and northerners who maintain a tentative peace, hold a closer connection to the land and the spirits of nature than any other nation.

For generations, an impenetrable fog has persisted over the lands of Charneault. The mist was harmless for centuries, just another natural sight to behold in a land of countless beauties and mysteries. In recent times, however, the fog has transformed into a malevolent force.

The King of Charneault, Thibault de Sauveterre, and the elven Archdruid, Aetherion, work to discover the truth behind this sudden change. The Charneault Kingdom now faces the specter of its history, an ambiguous future, and the mist encompassing it all.

entries.name: History
entries: Before there was a kingdom called Charneault, there was Caer Neiada, the "land of countless rivers" in the Elvish tongue. A verdant paradise of rolling hills and fertile wilderness that was isolated from other nations, Caer Neiada flourished on its own for centuries before the Era of Expansion.

entries.name: The Ulufey
entries: The first settlers of Caer Neiada called themselves the ulufey: "mortal fey" in Elvish. Believing they were the direct descendants of the Spirits of Nature, the children of the archfey, in everything they did they gave respect and offerings to the seasonal courts. The ulufey considered Caer Neiada to be their birthright.

Humankind first appeared in Caer Neiada like the embers of a forthcoming wildfire, drifting in from beyond the Grove Maze. When they first encountered the ulufey, they adopted the word into the human tongue—"elf."

Beholding the natural splendor of Caer Neiada, many believed this place was a haven from the mud and black forests of central Etharis, a gift given to them by the gods. Without heeding the Spirits of Nature, the settlers drank deeply of all the land had to offer.

Nearby elves were horrified by witnessing the ravaging of their lands. Worse, they feared the wrath of the archfey. Conflict between cultures was inevitable, as the elves tried to expel these foreigners from their realm and the northerners clung to their new homes. Armies arose on both sides, culminating in generations of war.

entries.name: Pact of the Sacred Land
entries: The first man to be king of Charneault was Aymeric Noblecoeur. Once a knight in service to Castle Lamesdhonneur, Noblecoeur was said to have been knocked from his horse by an arrow and washed away in the river currents.

He was found deep in Caer Neiada by an elven sage named Thuridan Sarador, who bathed his feet in a stream. A leader among his people, Sarador sat and spoke to Noblecoeur, explaining his vision for a united realm. Two cultures, one kingdom. The dream of Charneault.

The Pact of the Sacred Land outlines the peace between the northern folk and the elves, and their responsibilities in sharing the land. The Bondmakers commune with the Spirits of Nature directly. The king and his noble court rule, counseled by the Bondmakers of the archey's whims. The Chapter Knights protect the kingdom against invasion and maintain order between its peoples. Wealth and produce are shared. The sacred sites of elves are never disturbed.

entries.name: The Circle of Bondmakers
entries: There are two main faiths in the Charneault Kingdom. Belief in the Four Divines—Aurelia, Galt, Ulmyr, and Maligant—migrated south with the northern tribes. But the {@book Gods' End|GrimHollowPG24|9|The Gods' End} did not impact Charneault as it did other realms.

The elves would not call their relationship with the fey a religion. They view the Spirits of Nature as their true ancestors and the Courts of the archfey as a ruling authority above their own. The fey are not distant gods who answer the prayers of the downtrodden through goodwill. Elven customs are far more transactional. The Spirits of Nature demand that the wilderness be maintained.

The Circle of Bondmakers are a community of druids whose responsibility is maintaining the connection between the people of Charneault and the Spirits of Nature. They wander the Kingdom, strengthening or restoring the bonds with the Spirits, wherever the fey cause trouble.

The two faiths coexist in Charneault, often within the same settlement, influencing each other over the centuries. In modern times, northerners have created their own connections to the Spirits of Nature through knighthood and quests. Elven ideals of romance and beauty have suffused the northern culture to give rise to the Chapter Knights.

entries.name: Grand Shaman Aetherion
entries: Aetherion is a powerful archdruid named the leader of the Bondmakers in the aftermath of the slaughter that claimed Princess Tiphaine. Given the epithet "Fey Sighted," it's said the Spirits of Nature are willing to show this elf glimpses of the future. Whatever horrors he has witnessed, Aetherion remains silent as he works to undo them.

Despite this, Aetherion is a jovial and mischievous elf who enjoys spending time in others' company. He was a companion to King de Sauveterre during Thibault's questing days. Since the tragedy that unleashed the dark mist, a rift has opened between the two men.

Aetherion now rides across the Charneault Kingdom, recruiting knights and mercenaries to accomplish deeds that combat the dark mist. Yet his goals are not always clear in his requests. Only the Fey Sighted can see the tapestry of time, weaving together a future he desperately wishes to prevent.

entries.name: Knighthood
entries: Knighthood is the greatest aspiration of any child who comes of age in the Charneault Kingdom. A knight is expected to exemplify many virtues: courage, strength, and honor, as required by any warrior. Justice, temperance, and mercy. A knight may be needed to serve as a sheriff or judge to defend the realm's peace. Faith, generosity, and hope. The knights are the light of Charneault, and their ability to spread beauty and mirth is as important as their skill in swordsmanship.

The Chapter Knights are highly codified institutions that prioritize differing virtues. All serve the Charneault Kingdom. Yet their specific purposes and ideals differ. Becoming a Chapter Master, the leader of each knightly order, involves years of dedication and service to a chapter's cause and virtues.

There are five major knight chapters recognized as the most renowned in Charneault. Other, lesser chapters exist, though they attract fewer squires and tend to be specific in their cause. Knights-errant also wander the land looking for deeds to enact, though they bring no honor upon themselves. A knight without a chapter has no authority recognized by the Crown.

The Vermeil Guard acts as a personal guard of the Bondmakers, traversing Charneault with them wherever the druids may need. The Iron Sparrow oversees the general defense of Charneault, with subchapters stationed outside the Grove Maze, along the Rock-Teeth Mountains, and on the coastline. The Fairweathers patrol the mainland of Charneault, keeping the peace and rebuilding settlements after a conflict or the mist passing through. The Dawn Dreamers protect Tol Leyemil, though they live on the outskirts of the great city. The most contentious of the knight chapters is the Severe Templars, whose purpose is to map the land of Charneault and study its environments, which inevitably leads to conflict with the Spirits of Nature.

entries.name: The Dark Mist
entries: After generations of relative peace between the cultures of the Charneault Kingdom, relations took a grim turn when King Thibault de Sauveterre ascended the throne.

The King's firstborn daughter, Tiphaine de Sauveterre, knew it was her destiny to walk to the Temple of Mist and disappear forever: a sacrifice she made happily for the kingdom she loved. But the Princess' heart was also given to another.

Sir Guilhem le Preux was a famed knight of the Vermeil Guard. He'd sworn oaths to the Spirits of Nature. He'd slain werewolves and toppled giants. And, despite the Pact of the Sacred Land, he had also married Princess Tiphaine in secret.

When Thibault de Sauveterre was crowned, Sir Guilhem wept at his king's feet. The knight begged that Tiphaine be spared. It was the Princess herself who took her husband's hands and instructed him to be merry, for the sacrifice of their great love would forge the mightiest kingdom.

The Princess never reached the Temple of Mist, and her husband disappeared after following the procession there. What happened is a mystery that many feel set Charneault onto its current unsettling path.

entries.name: Provinces
entries: Charneault is comprised of seven provinces, each with its own expressions of elven and northern culture. Gran Croix is the realm of the Grove Maze. The western provinces of {@book Beaumont|GrimHollowPG24|8|Beaumont}, {@book De la Fontaine|GrimHollowPG24|8|De la Fontaine}, and {@book Faucher|GrimHollowPG24|8|Faucher} have higher elven populations and greater reverence for the Spirits of Nature. {@book Gagnon|GrimHollowPG24|8|Gagnon}, {@book Lamar|GrimHollowPG24|8|Lamar}, and {@book Chaplin|GrimHollowPG24|8|Chaplin} are home to more urbanized settlements and tend toward worship of the Arch Seraphs.

Before the Pact of the Sacred Land united them, each province was its own territory or kingdom. Some were ruled by a noble house whose descendants still govern to this day, now bearing the titles of duke or duchess. It's common for these noble families to include Chapter Knights among their lineages.

entries.name: Chaplin
entries: Bordering most other provinces, Chaplin is the crown jewel of the Charneault Kingdom and the birthplace of knightly virtue. It's the seat of the Crown's authority. It's also the wealthiest of any region, though its riches are not based on resources or even Crown taxes. Folks pour into Chaplin from across Charneault in the hopes of witnessing greatness.

Tensions in Chaplin have only risen as the dark mist spreads. In the face of mounting calamity, Castle Lamesdhonneur has been transformed into a refuge for many Charnelaise seeking shelter against the horror outside. The once-vibrant city is rife with nervous fear. In a time when he is most needed to bring hope, the noble King de Sauveterre has retreated from public life and left the Severe Templars to maintain order within Chaplin.

entries.name: King Thibault de Sauveterre
entries: Former Chapter Master of the Iron Sparrow, King de Sauveterre struggled to claim the throne in the face of dire competition from Hermand le Sévère. Thibault prevailed, though narrowly. Thibault's supporters thought he would be a lion among kings once he ascended the throne. Instead, he became a broken man after the tragedy that befell his daughter, Princess Tiphaine, and the subsequent spreading of the dark mist.

entries.name: Gagnon
entries: Gagnon is the easternmost duchy of Charneault and borders the Castinellan Provinces. Forts are built along the rivers that divide the two nations. Open hostility is rare, but Charneault is alert to the intolerance Castinella expresses towards druidic magic and the Spirits of Nature.

Gagnon is the home to the Iron Sparrow, whose knightly tradition is entwined with an appreciation of the inherent beauty in the natural world. Music is common in the streets of Camont. Sometimes it's a knight singing ballads by a fountain, reciting the deeds of the Iron Sparrow that keep the realm safe.

entries.name: Duchess Sylvana Briar Lorraine
entries: The young duchess of Camont is no more than five years old, orphaned after the recent death of her father, Duke Lothair Lorraine. Intrigues loom around Sylvana, as nobles scheme to make her ducal throne their own. Local gossip suggests that strange events surround Sylvanna, with some claiming she is cursed. Her father's elven steward, Edwardine Evrétte, oversees Sylvana's governance until she comes of age.

entries.name: Lamar
entries: Lamar is a bridge between east and west Charneault. Its midlands are mostly farms and roads, where commoners make humble livings whilst dreaming of knightly adventures and mystical Fey Courts.

Though often unseen, the Spirits of Nature are never far. The many bridges that cross the countless rivers, and guide stones marking directions beside the roads, are frequently destroyed—perhaps by mischievous faeries. Superstitious folk who fear fey retribution tear down structures built too close to sacred woods or faerie mounds.

entries.name: Dame Vivian Descoteaux
entries: Chapter Master of the Fairweathers, and mother to the current Duchess of Lamar, Vivian Descoteaux is an acclaimed knight. Formidable and determined, she is fixated on protecting Charneault's ideals and its citizens. She is a woman of deeds and few words, believing that it's in words where dishonesty hides.

entries.name: Grand Croix
entries: The Grove Maze has its own provincial name: Grand Croix. Most settlements are along the great forest's edge, though some communities choose to live within its fortress of trees. These villages are intimately shaped by elven culture. Homes are sometimes built aloft, among the branches of enormous trees, and connected by arching bridges and spiraling staircases. Many gnomes live here who carry a deep affinity for the Spirits of Nature. Some claim the Spirits of Nature secretly reside in these hamlets, hiding themselves when they hear horses approach.

The capital of the province is Besion, an ancient fortress built by Raulish hands along what had once been a southern frontier. The city changed its name and sovereignty many times through its long history, between the Bürach Empire and Charneault. Yet its identity has become firmly Charnelaise.

entries.name: Beaumont
entries: The land of the elves, Beaumont is the region that surrounds Tol Leyemil. The elves rarely delineated specific borders in the days of Caer Neiada, and therefore Beaumont is considered to include any part of northern Charneault from where the Rock-Teeth Mountains are visible.

With rugged foothills, coastal access, and a rich forest, Beaumont has the greatest diversity of resources among the provinces. The fish from the rivers, fruits from the trees, and metals from the base of the mountains provide plenty to trade with other regions. Boats built in Beaumont are also famed for their sleek designs and speed on the water.

The Acen Elavain, or the "Assembly of Elves," is the ruling council of Tol Leyemil here. However, their political power stretches further than just the elven city, and they advise the Crown of the Charneault Kingdom and negotiate on their people's behalf.

entries.name: Virion Venfir
entries: While no individual member is intended to have more authority than the others on the Acen Elavain, Virion's voice travels further and with more influence than the rest of the assembly. A musician of spectacular talent, Virion wields his popularity with the elves of Tol Leyemil to bring elven interests to the fore.

entries.name: De la Fontaine
entries: Deep in the Charneault Kingdom are the mystic lands of De la Fontaine. Here, the mist is ever present. The green hills and wide valleys always look as if painted in watercolors, studded with tiny villages of mostly elven heritage. Its many rivers are crossed at natural fords or on ferries made of grass. Agriculture remains small and haphazard, with wild orchards, berry thickets, and haggard lifestock roaming through unfenced pastures.
De la Fontaine seems an unwealthy province to its neighbors. But the small life suits its residents. They prefer hearing fairytales told over a warm fire, rather than participating in them.

Bonneseaux Village is the largest settlement of De la Fontaine, with a greater mix of heritages than the rest of the region. Nevertheless, it is small. Situated on a sloping hill on the south side of a lake, the village is surrounded by water, and houses are built upon stilts to remain dry.
South of De la Fontaine lies the Temple of Mist, making the Bondmakers and their knightly escorts a common sight. A druid is far more common than a priest in most villages.

entries.name: Duke Hugo Plomierre
entries: The halfling duke of De la Fontaine, Hugo Plomierre, spends much of his time on the Royal Council at Castle Lamesdhonneur, or as a guest at Camont or Mont de Lancey. Most recognize he is a shrewd politician, trusting the local reeves to handle administrative details in the province.

entries.name: Faucher
entries: In the furthest western reaches of Charneault, the land rots. The grass thins and turns grey. The trees distort and lose their leaves. The riches of the wilderness disappear, and Spirits of Nature fall silent near the boughs of the Dark Oak Grove.

The ruler of this land was an elven sorceress named Thaelkinei. Only the oldest elven texts contain any mention of her. In her time, it is said the lands were a garden paradise that teamed with the Spirits of Nature. Its capital of Tol Kerdywel was a city of white towers as beautiful as Tol Leyemil remains to this day.

Now, however, Thaelkinei, is remembered as the Lich Princess. She believed she could control the Spirits of Nature through arcane magic, intending to use this power to expel the northern tribes from Caer Neiada. It is told she wept above Tol Kerdywel when she heard of the bloodshed inflicted upon her people.

In the end, the Lich Princess was her own undoing. She was defeated by the combined human and elven forces, and her magic faded. However, myths from those times carry through to the present, and many say that the dark mists could be a sign of the Lich Princess's return.

A few elves quietly suggest that elven magic has weakened since the times of old, due to the presence of northern folk. They point to the dark forests of Faucher as where the secrets to rejuvenating elvish might await discovery.

entries.name: The Castinellan Provinces
entries: Castinella lies at the southernmost extent of Etharis. Its scorching heat and relentless dry winds make for a harsh climate, but the {@book Arcanist Inquisition's|GrimHollowPG24|10|The Arcanist Inquisition} unyielding theocratic control can make life in this peninsula truly difficult.

The state religion follows the Seraphs; in particular, {@book Arch Seraph Empyreus|GrimHollowPG24|9|Empyreus}. The Inquisition has made the law of the church the law of the land. Arcane magic is illegal, and its practitioners are subject to unpleasant fates, the least barbaric of which is death.
Castinella presents an image of order and safety, but this hides untold horrors that are more dangerous than the wildest forests or the deepest caves.

entries.name: The Unifier
entries: Since the Era of Expansion, Castinella's provinces have regularly fought for control. This changed when the conqueror-prophet Montego Valieda claimed that Arch Seraph Empyreus directed him to unify the provinces under the Seraph's divine laws. Valieda's teachings fell on receptive ears. Many were war-weary and eager for a unified Castinella. His divine teachings amassed support from nobles and commoners alike. Valieda and his followers overcame the final remnants of resistance, either with gold, or violently with iron and fire.

entries.name: Rise of the Inquisition
entries: Valieda's religious movement became known as the Arcanist Inquisition. Now formally named Sagredo Valieda, the Unifier preached that Empyreus had decreed that magic was a curse endangering its wielders and everyone associated with them.

At first, the Inquisition warned of magic's dangers, stirring mistrust in the population. After a time, they began to arrest anyone who was magically gifted. Eventually, Valieda proclaimed that all arcanists should be captured and put to death, regardless of their crimes or ability to control their magic. These deaths were seen as sad, solemn, and ultimately necessary for the betterment of all.
Today, most townsfolk claim they prefer life with the Inquisition in charge; roads are safer, markets are filled with goods, and there is always someone to call when magic threatens one's life.
You're safe from the Inquisitors as long as you don't use magic. Or know someone who does. Or know how to spell the word.

entries.name: Blasphemous Rumors
entries: The state religion stringently follows Arch Seraph Empyreus's divine laws as they were revealed to Valieda. A few who question the Inquisition's actions claim Valieda's divine tales are simply false. A few even suggest the Unifier did not receive his divine vision from an Arch Seraph but something malevolent, with dark whispers pointing to the {@book Arch Daemon Beleth|GrimHollowPG24|9|Beleth}. Though there are no sure truths to these rumors, some remark that Beleth is believed to take great pleasure in toying with divine servants.

entries.name: Exposing the Arcane
entries: The fear that arcane magic can hide in plain sight has propelled the clergy to use torture to uncover these evils. Once used as a last resort, torture is now a common occurrence, and with the recent command to purge all mages, torturing arcanists has been elevated to a more reverent form. Torture is frequently carried out in churches, with masses gathered to sing hymns while the captives are "cleansed" of their sins.

entries.name: Arcanists in Castinella
entries: Being magically gifted is a secret kept from one's closest friends and family. Magically talented children are often disowned for fear of attracting the church's punishment. The Inquisition has license to capture anyone from families with magical blood, even if they themselves are not gifted.

A few families successfully hide arcane talents by teaching children to conceal their magic. In some places, secret networks exist to train the arts of magical control, but all too often, the secret leaks, and the Inquisition is quick to strike.

entries.name: Curses and Transformations
entries: People cursed by powerful magic are shunned and treated with mistrust. In Castinella, it is illegal to exist in such a state, and one cannot openly search for a cure as the Inquisition demands a swift death for the afflicted. A black market exists for cures, though many cures offered are fake, while others are sold at monstrous prices. Few good-hearted folk exist willing to provide these cures for little or no cost.
Any transformation that results in a physical change is punishable by immediate death: no evidence, testimony, trial, or ceremony needed.

{@book Seraph transformations|GrimHollowPG24|8|Seraph} are the exception to this swift "justice," as they are seen as a gift, though the clergy debate whether these transformations are actually holy. A conclave of high-ranking Inquisition members convenes to study such individuals to ascertain if their gifts are truly holy or a sign of corruption.

entries.name: The Land
entries: Castinella is a massive peninsula with a mountain range running down its center. In the northern provinces, they are called the Corova Mountains and are famous for the wealth of resources mined there, which drive {@book Toletum's|GrimHollowPG24|8|Toletum} ever-working forges. In the south, particularly around {@book Ember Cairn|GrimHollowPG24|8|Ember Cairn}, these mountains are known as the Shattered Peaks, their irregular forms seemingly broken apart by some cataclysmic event.

The east coast of Castinella is wild and sparsely inhabited, exposed to the strong winds of the Great Eastern Sea. Its western coast faces the Gulf of Lions, which is busy with trade to {@book Morencia|GrimHollowPG24|8|The City of Morencia}, the {@book Charneault Kingdom|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Charneault Kingdom}, and lands beyond.

The great Salves River flows out of Charneault in the north, roughly parallel to the Gulf Coast and the Corova Mountains to Toletum. Halfway down the peninsula, the river splits with both channels flowing west to join the Gulf of Lions. The space between them belongs to the city of {@book Faro|GrimHollowPG24|8|Faro}, which enjoys a bountiful climate filled with fertile farmland, tall pines, and aspen groves.

In the south lies Therpena, consisting of wide coastal beaches, plains, and forested mountains below the Shattered Peaks. The southernmost extent is called Sante Viegre, which is filled with sunny hills and thriving vineyards.

entries.name: Dry Climate
entries: The Castinellan Provinces host a variety of environments, but all are characterized by a scarcity of fresh water. With little rainfall, farming takes great effort, forcing farms to cluster around irrigation gathered from the land's few rivers. Vineyards run from the green plains to climb the mountain's foothills, and orchards grow on the steep slopes of the Shattered Peaks.

Deserts interspersed with low-lying trees and brush spread between the mountains and the Great Eastern Sea. Rocky mesas and wind-hewn columns occasionally break through the desert floor. While sand is prevalent, there are few dunes.

Despite its dryness, the land supports a host of life suited to such conditions. However, the lack of water means that organic material rarely rots as it does in wetter climes. The dead slowly desiccate from exposure. Skeletons are picked clean by animals and last for years, bleached white by the sun.
Most of Castinella lives in cities and villages near the region's rare freshwater sources. The remainder of the peninsula is largely uninhabited, untamed land full of wonder and danger.

entries.name: Architecture
entries: Appearances matter in Castinella, with each province having developed a distinctive style. As religious fervor grew, so did the cathedrals. Each region built extravagant places of worship to demonstrate they were the most faithful followers of Empyreus.

The {@book Cathedral of Embers|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Cathedral of Embers} is a massive rock excavated to house the Arcanist Inquisition. It is open to the public but closely guarded. The clergy states that seraphs protect all who visit, though crossbow-armed inquisitors and other secret watchers keep watch over those within.

Statues of the Seraphs are found in urban centers. Some claim these statues will awaken to protect the righteous in a time of great need. The clergy's position on this prophecy has varied from declaring it abject blasphemy to religious canon. Most civilians know never to question the current interpretation.

Ruins litter the deserts and high mountains. Many believe they are the remains of a dragonborn civilization destroyed in the distant past. Contrasting with the elaborate buttresses and spires of current construction, these ancient edifices are simple and elegant, embodying designs lost to time.

entries.name: Provinces
entries: Modern Castinella consists of three provinces, {@book Faro|GrimHollowPG24|8|Faro}, {@book Toletum|GrimHollowPG24|8|Toletum}, and {@book Therpena|GrimHollowPG24|8|Therpena}, each of which is summarized below.

entries.name: Faro
entries: The city of Faro was founded ages ago, becoming a force to be reckoned with thanks to its fertile land and defensible position between cliffs and the sea.

When the Inquisition rose to power, the noble house of Faro resisted, unwilling to part with its power. The Inquisition launched a siege on the city, and it seemed that Faro would prevail. However, on the twelfth day of the blockade, Faro soldiers began slaughtering each other. This madness spread quickly, leaving the city panicked and defenseless. It is said that Faro's noble family retreated into the cliffs behind their palace, never to be seen again.

The Inquisition guards the abandoned palace and the cliff's stone doors, claiming the noble family's heretical tendencies have tainted them with dark magic. Rumors persist that weeping can be heard behind these closed doors, though the clergy reject this.

entries.name: A Dark Center
entries: The outskirts of Faro thrive thanks to a strong shipping trade and bountiful farming, but things sour as one approaches the palace in the city's center. The Inquisition never forgave Faro for its resistance and now rules the city with an iron hand. Festivals are often somber and quiet, with heavy tones of religious indoctrination. Performers know not to perform content that could be construed as heretical. High taxes offset the city's bountiful trade. More executions take place here than in any other province, while whispers of rebellion swirl.

entries.name: The White Fleet
entries: The city's docks are bright and perpetually busy with trade. It is home to the White Fleet, Castinella's navy, arguably one of the strongest in all of Etharis. The Inquisition is vigilant here, ensuring that no arcane threats enter. Though they pay lip service to the church, the sailors of the White Fleet are happy to be away from the Inquisition's prying eyes and accusing stares.

entries.name: Noble Houses
entries: The collapse of the House of Faro has left a power vacuum that is yet to be filled. Many minor noble houses scrabble for influence, but the Inquisition maintains a tight grip on all city activities. Whenever a house grows too powerful, it will invariably be brought low by the combined actions of smaller houses collaborating to prevent such an ascension, either through economic means or direct assassination if necessary.
When House Faro returns to its former glory, the Inquisition will know what true wrath looks like.

entries.name: Toletum
entries: Toletum's great city is frequently cloaked in noxious smoke from its constantly running forges. Most of the ore mined in the Corova Mountains is processed in the lower city, fabricating arms and weaponry in quantities that dwarf production elsewhere in Castinella.

The upper city is home to wealthy bureaucrats. Administrators and heads of businesses significantly influence legislative oversight of the peninsula. There is also pressure to expand the Inquisition far beyond the reaches of Castinella. The likelihood that this could instigate wars with other nations does not seem to bother these war enthusiasts and their well-built infrastructure for selling military supplies.

entries.name: Toletum Crime
entries: Organized crime is entrenched throughout the city, with a vibrant black market that resells stolen military armaments. Weapons, magical potions, spell scrolls, and arcane focuses cannot be procured legally, but they can be found if one knows where to ask the right questions.

Since arcane magic is illegal, many arcanists surviving in Castinella can make a good living using their talents for unlawful means. The Castibona family is one of these. The city's lawkeepers doggedly pursue them because many of Castibona's arcanists do jobs that oppose the Inquisition's war on magic. Their services are expensive, but they are best positioned to help someone escape the Inquisition's clutches.

In its campaign to root out the Castibonas, the Inquisition has contracted sympathetic crime syndicates that do not tolerate magic users. As such, fences and dealers exist who can procure illicit substances or dangerous weapons, and maybe even a magical potion or scroll. However, these dealers are quick to sell out individuals to the Inquisition if it becomes beneficial for them to do so.

entries.name: Therpena
entries: Therpena enforces the same harsh laws as the other provinces, but the general mood here is more joyful. This doesn't mean the Arcanist Inquisition is lax.

When the Inquisition came to power, they took Ember Cairn and the Shattered Peaks as their headquarters. The sunny hills now live within the shadow of the Inquisition and its much stricter rule. Local guardsmen are often less harsh and more forgiving than in other parts of the peninsula. In contrast, church enforcers are twice as diligent when the Inquisition's watchful eye is so close.

entries.name: Center of Art and Culture
entries: Therpena's noble houses have long been famous for the arts. This focus has led to freer and more joyful people, at least on the surface.

Today, most art celebrates the goodness of the Arch Seraphs and the fight against the evils of the arcane and Daemons. The church censures anything it deems heretical, and it burns books of magic gathered by the Inquisition. Many artistic works have been destroyed in the name of Empyreus.

Therpena's music and drama are without equal, attracting musicians from other lands to perform in the city. The competition for prestige is fierce. Audiences are discerning, and the skills that would win lucrative work in other kingdoms might garner only modest compensation here.

entries.name: The Calcien Family
entries: Thus far, the Inquisition has never thoroughly raided the Calcien family's many residences. Despite suggestions that the noble house has stockpiles of heretical art, cursory reviews have only uncovered appropriately reverent pieces.

The unspoken and publicly known secret is that the Calcien family generously supports the church, for which most of the family's activities are ignored. This includes the family's magical history from the time before the Inquisition. Accusations are said quietly, as many family members are part of the clergy, and their roots within the church run deep.

entries.name: Ember Cairn
entries: Destroyed long ago, the granite city of Ember Cairn stands atop the Shattered Peaks. It was rebuilt and repopulated by the once-nomadic dragonborn. It is the strictest and most regulated of Castinella's cities. Despite this, a black market still flourishes in the shadows.

There is a growing interest in uncovering the history of the dragonborn, dragons, and the secrets of the city's original destruction. The Inquisition carefully monitors this. They are concerned, as dragons were rumored to have been talented practitioners of arcane magic.

entries.name: The Cathedral of Embers
entries: Looming over Ember Cairn, the headquarters of the Arcanist Inquisition stands in the city's heart. As the church's seat of power, it is beautiful, solemn, and deadly for those who practice arcane magic or oppose the Castinellan government.

Many have heard of a labyrinth hidden beneath the Cathedral, where the Inquisition throws unfortunate arcanists they have captured. Some joke that food waste is dropped within, not to feed its prisoners but instead the many monsters rumored to lurk there. The extent of the Labyrinth is unknown. Some believe its passageways spread for miles as tales persist of miners intersecting its tunnels when they dig too deeply beneath the Shattered Peaks. Some seek out the Labyrinth, enticed by promises of lost treasures, untold wealth, and magical cures lost within.

entries.name: Hedric, the High Redeemer
entries: The leader of the Arcanist Inquisition's troops is an aging black dragonborn with a lower jaw misshapen by a scar. His hatred of arcane magic perfectly aligns with the goals and methods of the Inquisition. He sees danger everywhere, actively rooting out corruption with fanatical zeal, swiftly executing the High Inquisitor's directives.

entries.name: The Empyrean Pit
entries: Fighting pits where warriors fight hand-to-hand are growing in popularity. Ember Cairn's Empyrean Pit is the newest and most elaborate fighting arena in Castinella. It contains artwork from the most talented artisans of the day. Grand pit fighting spectacles are presented several times a month under the clergy's watchful eye. It's not unheard of for the Inquisition to quickly arrest combatants who accidentally reveal arcane powers in the heat of battle.

entries.name: The Valikan Clans
entries: In the far north, at the frozen edge of Etharis, spreads the home of the Valikan clans. It is a harsh land of short summers and frigid winters where the weak northern sun can fail to rise above the horizon.

The dangers of this land are both natural and supernatural. Its people have a hardened tenacity that is steeped in traditions of violence, not just to survive but also as a religious necessity to forestall the end of the world.

entries.name: Gormadraug and the Seven Heroes
entries: Ancient legends speak of a time when mighty {@book Primordials|GrimHollowPG24|9|The Primordials} rivaled the power of the gods. {@book Gormadraug|GrimHollowPG24|8|Gormadraug and the Seven Heroes}, the Great Prismatic Wyrm, was the mightiest, leaving destruction in his wake and coldfire erupting at every step.

Eventually, seven mortal heroes rose against the Primordials. The great {@book Kentigern|GrimHollowPG24|9|The Kentigern Saga} led this mythic band, defeating hordes of Elementals until finally facing Gormadraug himself. Despite being swallowed by the Great Wyrm, the heroes slayed it from within, and thus, the north was tamed. People soon arrived, forming six major clans, each taking the name of one of the legendary heroes who killed the Great Wyrm.
However, legends also state that Gormadraug was not truly defeated but is merely sleeping. It is prophesized that the Great Wyrm will one day rise again to consume the world.

entries.name: Raiding and Thralls
entries: Valika's brief growing season and limited resources have created a culture where raiding is seen as a necessity and an acceptable way of life. These raids inspire a deep fear across Etharis, where every spring, coastal settlements watch for longships on the horizon.

Valika is built on the labor of captured folk bonded to servitude. Raiding for thralls is an ancient clan tradition that most have no perspective to question. The north is a harsh land with few settlements, and the Valikans have never had enough people to farm, mine, fish, or hunt. A millennia ago, the clans looked southward for the folk they needed to keep their settlements and culture alive.

Captured thralls are returned to Valika and bonded for a fixed term of no more than five years. For most, it is a difficult but not insurmountable trial. A thrall's treatment varies from clan to clan, but generally, they are considered part of the community as they live, work, and eat alongside the clanfolk they serve. They enjoy the same freedom of movement as other clan members, but thralls captured alone outside their communities are easy fodder for the {@book Prismatic Circle's|GrimHollowPG24|10|The Prismatic Circle} sacrifices, wild beasts of the land, or the weather.

The Valikan clans also raid each other endlessly. Folk captured by another clan can be bonded into servitude as easily as those of foreign lands. However, such local raids effectively see the clans only trading members back and forth, so they focus more on stealing portable wealth, leaving thrall raids to the fleets reaving in the south.

entries.name: The Land
entries: This cold northern domain is immense, and its geography varies greatly. The inhospitable lands have forced those who live here to take extreme measures to survive.

entries.name: Grarjord
entries: Many southerners refer to the entirety of the north as Grarjord, but this ancient name only represents Valika's southernmost extent. It is where {@book Bürach's|GrimHollowPG24|8|The Bürach Empire} vast temperate woods give way to the open tundra, steep peaks, and cold forests surrounding the jagged fjord-cut peninsulas of the Teeth.

Grarjord is nominally under the control of {@book Thrull|GrimHollowPG24|8|Thrull}, with many minor clans living here to avoid the militaristic posturing of Clan Völgr. Resources remain scarce, and inter-clan relationships are often defined by raiding and blood feuds.

The beacon city of Halsfjord stands along the steep hills lining the fjord that shares its name. This is the seat of Clan Rune and where the clan's renowned skill with spellcraft is nurtured. The city is a repository of magical knowledge rivaling any arcane college in southern Etharis.

The sprawling port town of Skarfanes was a Valikan watchpost captured by the Bürach Empire some sixty years ago. The empire made the town an open trading hub, hoping to quell northern raids. Today, an imperial garrison protects the town, but local clan traders largely control it.

Given Thrull's perceived control of Grarjord, the Prismatic Circle's theocratic dictates hold sway, including the demands for isolationism and forbidding trade with outsiders, causing Skarvanes to be seen as a black market. However, these clans of Thrull circumvent the Circle's restrictions by secretly trading with smaller local clans less beholden to the Grand Druid's control.

entries.name: Thrull
entries: Thrull lies north of Grarjord, stretching from the island of Holgar to the foothills of the Grensfal Mountains. Much of this land lies north of the Circle of Shadow, an imaginary line marking the boundary of endless days and nights at the summer and winter solstices.

Much of Thrull is a vast tundra landscape, with seemingly endless stretches of rock, grass, and lichen, occasionally punctuated by great groves of oaks. These treed areas are known as Sentinel Woods, where the soil has turned blood-black from generations of murderous sacrifice by the {@book Prismatic Circle|GrimHollowPG24|10|The Prismatic Circle}. Nothing is known to lie north of Thrull, save the unforgiving Sea of Turmoil, where an ocean of restless ice hides leviathans in its frigid depths.

Tyburn, on the island of Holgar, is a bustling port and the seat of {@book Clan Völgr|GrimHollowPG24|8|Clan Völgr}, arguably the most dominant of Thrull's clans. Each raiding season, Völgr's fearsome longships depart from here to accost the south. Adding to its fearsome reputation is Hjadana, the Prsimatic Circle's Grand Druid. Her leadership influences nearly everything in Thrull, effectively making it a theocracy under her control.

Borgund, the City of Forges, is the most northern settlement on mainland Thrull and the seat of {@book Clan Sýr|GrimHollowPG24|8|Clan Sýr}. It is a massive complex built within the Armarka Mountains. Beneath stone-walled houses atop mountainside terraces is a vast network of chambers extending deep into the stony depths. Its great underground forges provide testament to Clan Sýr's legendary metalworking skills. Many of its citizens are thralls who elected to join Clan Sýr when their term of service ended, dedicating themselves to the artistry of metal.

Near central Thrull is the great frozen lake of Frostmere, which shares its name with an icy, frost giant fortress. These giants nurture a hatred of all people traveling across the nearby tundra, killing any they come into conflict with. A small minority of these giants ignore "the warm folk," and even fewer quietly trade with the clans.

entries.name: Hjadana, Grand Druid of the Prismatic Circle
entries: As the spiritual leader of Thrull, Hjadana uses her guile and the ferocious might of Clan Völgr to enforce a single vision of battle and sacrifice. The return of coldfire to the northlands has the Circle fearful that the Great Prismatic Wyrm is beginning to wake. This has spurred the circle to demand more sacrifices for the blood rites in the Sentinel Woods.

entries.name: Kandar
entries: Kandar is home to the three major clans—{@book Limgri|GrimHollowPG24|8|Clan Limgri}, {@book Mithra|GrimHollowPG24|8|Clan Mithra}, and {@book Morgöng|GrimHollowPG24|8|Clan Morgöng}—who are opposed to Thrull and the Prismatic Circle's theocratic control. The united clans of Kandar keep watch for incursions along the region's disputed plain of tundra spreading down from the Foxwood Range.

In the far east, the converted monastery of Fort Kentigern is now the last shield against encroaching waves of coldfire spreading across the ice bridge from the Volgen peninsula. The coldfire threat is dire, with many seeing it as an omen of doom and perhaps the return of Gormadraug. The Order of Kentigern welcomes all within the fort, making it a haven for reformed criminals and exiles willing to battle the coldfire threat.

Solheim sits on Shadow Storm Gulf and is the only notable settlement of Clan Limgri. It is the smallest of Kandar's three cities and was once the religious center of Valika. It is home to the Sun Temple, the city's most beautiful structure, which was abandoned after the fall of the gods. Some claim the temple's walls reveal secrets when the sun's fleeting summer rays shine across its runic inscriptions. Today, only the city's shipyards grant a modicum of pride to its residents, where an atmosphere of doom pervades even during the longest summer days.

Hrist is the cultural center of Kandar and its largest and most cosmopolitan city, welcoming merchants and diplomats from the southern lands. It is the seat of Clan Mithra, with Queen Andrea Helsing ruling from the Great Hall's Sommer Throne. The city is also home to the Skald Library, whose collections are among the greatest in all of Etharis. It notably holds several pristine copies of the Lord Edda, the codified oral legends of the Valikan clans.

Further south is Summerhelm, Kandar's second-largest city and the seat of Clan Morgöng. It is generally accepted as Kandar's southernmost extent, despite Runeheim being even further south. Summerhelm's construction is reminiscent of the southern kingdoms, particularly the Summer Palace, which is built like a typical Ostoyan castle. Tall shadows from massive outer walls give the city a shadowy atmosphere, which suits the illicit drug trade prospering within.

Skuggiskogr Forest's shadowy pines spread from Summerhelm to Shadow Storm Gulf. Few enter the woods for fear of the fey who are said to hide within. These dark trees press against the Grey Spine Mountains, physically separating Valika from the sunless lands of Ostoya to the south.

entries.name: Volgen
entries: Though the north poses uncountable dangers, many fear the most significant threat is coldfire spreading from the Volgen peninsula. This phenomenon resembles bluish flames that burn on ice, snow, plants, and animals. Anything it meets burns like oil. Water cannot douse it; only the hottest flames can put it out.

Frozen Cinnabar is a recent casualty of coldfire, a once-vibrant fishing community now encased in ice. A rescue mission sent from Fort Kentigern failed to return. Most believe the village is now haunted by ghosts seeking vengeance on the living.

entries.name: Cinderghast
entries: Cinderghast is comprised of several volcanic islands north of Kandar. Legends speak of a time when settlements flourished with fertile soil, rich crops, and a happy people. That was, until Rune of the Seven Heroes trapped the salamander Ixlalu, after which the land erupted to become today's poisoned landscape. It is widely believed that the land is cursed, though a few scholars have braved the journey, discovering vast ruins covered in ash and rock.

entries.name: The Clans
entries: In Valika, six major clans have survived for countless generations, each with a unique culture derived from one of Kentigern's band of heroes. Some cling to the old ways of raiding and thralldom, while others now rely on trade, diplomacy, and espionage to gain what they need.

The clans of {@book Thrull|GrimHollowPG24|8|Thrull}—Clans Rune, Sýr, and Völgr—fervently follow the Prismatic Circle and its Grand Druid Hjadana. The Circle preaches that conflict, raiding, and bloodshed are needed to keep the Great Prismatic Wyrm quiescent. Failing to do so will awaken Gormadraug, heralding the world's end.

The major clans of {@book Kandar|GrimHollowPG24|8|Kandar}—Clans Mithra, Morgöng, and Limgri—do not follow the Prismatic Circle's dictates. Though they still raid, these clans see greater opportunities in trade with the south, which clashes with the teachings of the Prismatic Order's Grand Druid. Raids against Kandar from Thrull have escalated, forcing the eastern clans to create standing armies and erect fortifications to protect against incursion.

entries.title: Valikan Clan Emblems (Row 1, L-R) Clan Sýr—Clan Mithra—Clan Limgri (Row 2, L-R) Clan Völgr—Clan Morgöng—Clan Rune

entries.name: Clan Rune
entries: Magic lies at the heart of Clan Rune. Its settlements are sheltered by spellcraft, and its children are watched carefully for hints of magical talent. The settlement's masters teach anyone demonstrating such ability.

As with all Valikan clans, large numbers of Rune folk become warriors, with some being capable arcanists focusing on defense and battle. For those without arcane skills, wielding runestones provides a satisfactory compromise.

entries.name: Ordun Doransson
entries: The chief of Clan Rune is a powerful mage, claiming the title after his mother's death some fifteen years ago. He is both a formidable rune mage and a potent war chief. He is patient and careful with his actions. Most suspect he has visions of being anointed Keeper of the Three Tribes, but thus far, he has avoided raising the ire of Clan Völgr's leader.

entries.name: Clan Sýr
entries: The most legendary metalworkers of the north hail from Clan Sýr. At ten years of age, clan members are bonded to the Järnförning, a hierarchy of labor, responsibility, and authority that shapes the lives of all clanfolk. The Järnförning is both a guild and a school, set up as twelve tiers of knowledge and skill running from apprentice to clan master.

Most Sýr settlements rise around iron, copper, tin, silver, gold, and rarer adamantine deposits. The clan produces its share of capable warriors. However, the defense of settlements is generally left to bonded thralls and the cunning mechanical traps afforded by the clan's mastery of metalwork.

entries.name: Brokyr Bladesinger
entries: Once a dwarf thrall captured as a child, Brokyr rose through the ranks of Borgund's metalsmiths. She eventually earned the title of sarvif of Clan Sýr thanks to the sublime and deadly beauty of her metalsmithing. She remains dedicated to raising the clan's metalworking skill and has been vocal about reducing the amount of Sýr goods smuggled to southern markets.

entries.name: Clan Völgr
entries: Clan Völgr's hierarchy is established by dominance, with the strongest and hardiest inevitably rising to positions of authority. But strength is reckoned in many ways among the Völgr. Even the most powerful warriors often willingly pay fealty to figures with weaker martial attributes who have proven leadership and tactical acumen.

Chief Nolgr Magnusson, who has ruled the clan for nearly thirty years, stands atop the clan. He is also Keeper of the Three Tribes, a title bestowed by the {@book Prismatic Circle|GrimHollowPG24|10|The Prismatic Circle}, which effectively makes him master of all Thrull-based clans.

entries.name: Nolgr Magnusson
entries: The towering chief of Clan Völgr is nearing fifty, yet appears to retain all the strength and passion of his youth. He has a close relationship with Hjadana, the Grand Druid of the Prismatic Circle. The Circle invested Nolgr as Keeper of the Three Tribes, effectively making him the leader of all of Thrull. Though his loyal warriors continue to sing his praises, a few quietly whisper that their chief does not strike with the same ferocity as he once did.

entries.name: Clan Mithra
entries: Clan Mithra is the most cosmopolitan and inviting to people from beyond Valika's borders. The clan views themselves as a force for order in the surrounding chaos, embodying the legacy of Mithra of the Silver Harp by embracing musical ability and world-spanning knowledge.

entries.name: Queen Andrea Helsing
entries: The clan is governed by their elected leader, Queen Andrea. She has allied with the other Kandar clans to protect against increasing Thrull incursions and is the war chief of the alliance. Preferring diplomacy, Queen Andrea still hopes that there can be a solution to the conflict with their western clans beyond the continued loss of life. Thus far, violence seems to be the only answer their foes will accept.

entries.name: Clan Morgöng
entries: Despite being allied with the more enlightened clans of Kandar, Clan Morgöng still regularly engages in summer raids and the taking of thralls from southern lands, particularly from Ostoyan coastal villages. These thralls often find a better life in Valika than what they faced under the Crimson Court's oppression. As such, many join the clan once their term is complete, making Clan Morgöng even more diverse than Clan Mithra. This diversity also allows the clan to send spies across Etharis, letting them deal in secrets more than any other export.

entries.name: Jarl Birger av Summerhelm
entries: Clan Morgöng lacks anything resembling a centralized government, though Jarl Summerhelm holds a hereditary title as ruler of the clan's capital. He is often absent, more interested in expanding his influence in foreign lands than overseeing the city.

entries.name: Clan Limgri
entries: Clan Limgri is the most nomadic of the six major tribes.

Hospitality is the clan's one governing law. All that they have is shared with those encountered in the wilderness. As a result, the Limgri are frequently the victims of Völgr raids, who take advantage of the clan's generosity.

entries.name: Jarl Angrboða Grata and Taala Brightstar
entries: Outsiders believe Jarl Angrboða and her advisor, Taala Brightstar, speak for the clan. This is mostly true, though the jarl and druid have little impact over how Limgri communities operate; the two are just the most in touch with the clan's elders. In the face of increased Thrull incursions, and unwilling to change their clan's cultural laws, the two petitioned Queen Andrea to extend Mithra outposts further north. In exchange, Clan Limgri agreed to control Cold Iron Keep, which houses the most dangerous, non-Valikan criminals in Kandar.

entries.name: Lesser Clans
entries: Though the six major clans dominate life in Valika, dozens of smaller clans exist as scattered enclaves across the north. These clans range in size and strength from small settlements of less than twenty souls to ones that might soon grow to rival the leading six.
Jarl Summerhelm's away again.
Must be the cold's getting to him.

entries.name: The City of Liesech
entries: Liesech is a perfect port, primarily reached by boat. Bite Bay's open waters and deep-sea ridge allow vessels to anchor closer to the shore. Transiting ships can skirt the coastlines in inclement weather, but ship captains must be vigilant. The turbulent currents of the surrounding waters have been known to throw vessels off course into sea stacks, exciting sea monsters rumored to dwell in the nearby area called the "Eye of the Sea."

Liesech's many channels and ditches keep tide swells at bay. Landforms corral coastal winds, keeping temperatures mild and warm. Waning sea storms in warmer periods deliver light rains that barely supports agriculture. Outsiders opine the sparse rainfall is due to the haze hanging over the city. Locals simply shrug their shoulders when asked.

entries.name: History
entries: Liesecher trace their origins to Otto Bouwengracht, whose family was influential when it was just a large fishing village. Ambitious and daring, Bouwengracht fished beyond safe waters, where he hoped to net larger catches. Before long, he became a wealthy merchant, with his family and those who trusted him rising to prominence. Liesech prospered under his leadership. He constructed a remarkable fleet of sailing ships. He sent his fleet to establish trading routes across the Emerald Sea and further. Liesech continued to grow, and with the revered Bouwengracht family as its voice, Liesech pronounced itself a free city.

entries.name: The Death of the Bouwengrachts and Rise of the Countess
entries: One day, the Bouwengracht family, along with other noble families, were found brutally killed—the blood entirely drained from their bodies. Almost immediately, the threats from Bite Bay and the Eye of the Sea returned. Terrible tides brought forth monsters that overran the docks. Destructive swells of flotsam and waste rolled into Liesech's shores—toppling buildings, drowning many, and delivering undulating, many-mouthed and tentacled monsters who consumed any in their path.

A savior stepped forward in the form of a recently arrived noble: Analita von Raiza marshalled troops and used magic to fight the incursion. On several occasions, the woman sailed out toward the Eyes of the Sea to find the source of the trouble.
After many days of turmoil and death, the seas calmed. The newly crowned Countess von Raiza returned and established her home at the {@book High Belfry|GrimHollowPG24|8|Notable Locations}.

entries.name: The Weeping Pox
entries: In the days following the conflict at the Eye of the Sea, Liesechers thought the worst was over. They were wrong. Disease swept through Liesech in the form of the Weeping Pox. The symptoms and consequences of the disease were like Etharis had never seen.

Days following exposure, the victim expresses hyper-vigilance and excitability, followed by bouts of delirium and fever. In its final stages, flesh takes on a bone-white pallor, and two bright red pustules appear on the neck. Right before death, melancholia sweeps over the victim as it weeps all the blood from its body and looses a final, powerful, painful wail.
The Weeping Pox claimed thousands.

In time, allied aid arrived in the form of the {@book Morbus Doctore|GrimHollowPG24|10|Morbus Doctore}. Their arrival sparked hope, but they could not fully stem the tide of death—only offer some relief to the pain. The masked countenances of the medically trained doctors remain a constant reminder of the death and danger that strike down citizens of Liesech every day.

entries.name: The Liesecher Way
entries: Most Liesechers make their way from their homes to their fishing boats and businesses after five morning bell tolls from the High Belfry. After six evening bell tolls, business dealings move from district streets to inside buildings. Those folks who are out beyond six bells are believed to be employed by the {@book Golden Barge Company|GrimHollowPG24|8|Important Factions}—or one of the foolish that risk becoming an addition to the accepted nightly disappearances.

The Weeping Pox is a part of everyday life in Liesech, and the populace does whatever is necessary to keep up their spirits in the midst of death and misery. Locals call the Pox a necessity. They insist it prevents overpopulation and keeps visitors fearful from staying too long. They note with feigned relief how the disease spares children—although the children still bear its disfiguring marks and spread the disease like anyone else.

Despite many losses, it has not claimed the city's revered Countess von Raiza, who the locals say miraculously managed trade to break the Bürach Empire's oppressive blockade. Citizens point to the arrival of the Morbus Doctore, who aid the sick and troubled.

entries.name: Countess Analita Von Raiza
entries: Liesech's interim leader has become an enigmatic figure since rescuing Liesech from the sea-spawned threats after the death of the city's ruling family. When she first arrived in the city, she was constantly seen in public, attending events frequently. Her beauty and charm were renowned, and her popularity in high society rivaled even the Bouwengrachts.

In the wake of the terrible attacks, she has taken on the mantle of leadership but has not appeared in public. In the face of the Weeping Pox, the citizenry appreciates what she's done and how she's been able to keep order, but they wonder about her condition.

entries.name: Cult of the Black Lady
entries: Countess von Raiza has not been seen in public since her battle with the mysterious power that lives in the Eye of the Sea. Her orders are carried out by a group that claims to work on her behalf: the Cult of the Black Lady.
